<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G entered into a full requirements contract through 2007 with Power to meet the supply requirements of PSE&amp;G&#39;s gas customers. Power has entered into hedges for a portion of its anticipated BGSS obligations, as permitted by the BPU. The BPU permits recovery of the cost of gas hedging up to&nbsp;115 billion cubic feet or approximately 80% of PSE&amp;G&#39;s residential gas supply annually through the BGSS tariff. For additional information, see Note&nbsp;13. Related-Party Transactions.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Minimum Fuel Purchase Requirements</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Power purchases coal for certain of its fossil generation stations through various long-term commitments. The total minimum purchase requirements included in these commitments amount to approximately $718 million through 2012.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Power has various multi-year requirements-based purchase commitments that average approximately $89 million per year to meet Salem&#39;s and Hope Creek&#39;s nuclear fuel needs, of which Power&#39;s share is approximately $64 million per year through 2010. Power has been advised by the co-owner and operator of Peach Bottom, Exelon Generation&nbsp;LLC (Exelon Generation), that it has similar purchase contracts to satisfy the fuel requirements for Peach Bottom through 2010, of which Power&#39;s share is approximately $31 million per year.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In addition to its fuel requirements, Power has entered into various multi-year contracts for firm transportation and storage capacity for natural gas, primarily to meet its gas supply obligations to PSE&amp;G. As of June&nbsp;30, 2006, the total minimum requirements under these contracts were approximately $1.2 billion through 2016.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>These purchase obligations are aligned with Power&#39;s strategy to enter into contracts for its fuel supply in comparable volumes to its sales contracts.</font></p>
<p align=center>32</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The Guadalupe and Odessa plants of Texas Independent Energy,&nbsp;L.P. (TIE), an indirect, wholly owned subsidiary of Energy Holdings, have entered into gas supply agreements for their anticipated fuel requirements to satisfy obligations under their forward energy sales contracts. As of June&nbsp;30, 2006, the Guadalupe and Odessa plants, which total approximately 2,000 MW of capacity, had forward energy sales contracts in place which support the majority of margin expectations for the balance of 2006. The plants had fuel purchase commitments totaling $82 million to fully support such contracts.</font><b><font color=#000000> </font></b><font color=#000000>TIE has also entered into an agreement to sell approximately 18% of its aggregate capacity for 2007 through 2010.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Operating Services Contract (OSC)</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Nuclear has entered into an&nbsp;OSC with Exelon Generation, which commenced on January&nbsp;17, 2005, relating to the operation of the Hope Creek and Salem nuclear generating stations. The OSC requires Exelon Generation to provide a chief nuclear officer and other key personnel to oversee daily plant operations at the Hope Creek and Salem nuclear generating stations and to implement the Exelon Generation operating model, which defines practices that Exelon Generation has used to manage the operations of its own nuclear facilities. Nuclear continues as the license holder with exclusive legal authority to operate and maintain the plants, retains responsibility for management oversight and has full authority with respect to the marketing of its share of the output from the facilities. Exelon Generation is entitled to receive
reimbursement of its costs in discharging its obligations, an annual operating services fee of $3 million and incentive fees up to $12 million annually based on attainment of goals relating to safety, capacity factor and operation and maintenance expenses. The OSC has a term of two years, subject to earlier termination in certain circumstances. In the event of termination, Exelon Generation will continue to provide services under the OSC for a transition period of at least&nbsp;180 days and up to two years at the election of Nuclear. This period may be further extended by Nuclear for up to an additional&nbsp;12 months if Nuclear determines that additional time is necessary to complete required activities during the transition period.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Maintenance Agreement</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Power entered into a long-term contractual services agreement with a vendor in September 2003 to provide the outage and service needs for certain of Power&#39;s fossil generating units at market rates. The contract covers approximately 25 years and could result in annual payments ranging from approximately $10 million to $50 million for services, parts and materials rendered.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Nuclear Fuel Disposal</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Under the Nuclear Waste Policy Act of 1982, as amended (NWPA), the Federal government has entered into contracts with the operators of nuclear power plants for transportation and ultimate disposal of spent nuclear fuel. To pay for this service, nuclear plant owners are required to contribute to a Nuclear Waste Fund at a rate of one mil ($0.001) per kWh of nuclear generation, subject to such escalation as may be required to assure full cost recovery by the Federal government. Under the NWPA, the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) was required to begin taking possession of the spent nuclear fuel by no later than 1998. The DOE has announced that it does not expect a facility for such purpose to be available earlier than 2017.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Pursuant to NRC rules, spent nuclear fuel generated in any reactor can be stored in reactor facility storage pools or in independent spent fuel storage installations located at reactors or away-from-reactor sites for at least&nbsp;30 years beyond the licensed life for reactor operation (which may include the term of a revised or renewed license). Adequate spent fuel storage capacity is estimated to be available through</font></p>
<p align=center>33</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>2011 for Salem&nbsp;1, 2015 for Salem&nbsp;2 and 2007 for Hope Creek. Power has commenced construction of an on-site storage facility that will satisfy the spent fuel storage needs of both Salem and Hope Creek through the end of their current respective license lives. Exelon Generation has advised Power that it has a licensed and operational on-site storage facility at Peach Bottom that will satisfy Peach Bottom&#39;s spent fuel storage requirements until at least 2014.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Exelon Generation had previously advised Power that it had signed an agreement with the DOE, applicable to Peach Bottom, under which Exelon Generation would be reimbursed for costs incurred resulting from the DOE&#39;s delay in accepting spent nuclear fuel for permanent storage. Under this agreement, Power&#39;s portion of Peach Bottom&#39;s Nuclear Waste Fund fees was reduced by approximately $18 million through August&nbsp;31, 2002, at which point credits were fully utilized and covered the cost of Exelon Generation&#39;s on-site storage facility. In September 2002, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit issued an opinion upholding a petition seeking to set aside the receipt of these credits by Exelon Generation. On August&nbsp;14, 2003, Exelon Generation received a letter from the DOE demanding repayment
of previously received credits from the Nuclear Waste Fund. The letter also demanded a total of approximately $1.5 million of accrued interest. In August 2004, Exelon Generation advised Nuclear that it reached a settlement with the U.S. Department of Justice, under which Exelon Generation would be reimbursed for costs associated with the storage of spent nuclear fuel at the Peach Bottom facility, a portion of which would be paid to Nuclear as a co-owner of Peach Bottom. Future costs incurred resulting from the DOE delays in accepting spent fuel will be reimbursed annually until the DOE fulfills its obligation to accept spent nuclear fuel. In addition, Exelon Generation and Nuclear are required to reimburse the DOE for the previously received credits from the Nuclear Waste Fund, plus lost earnings. Under this settlement, Power received approximately $27 million for its share of previously
incurred storage costs for Peach Bottom, $22 million of which was used for the required reimbursement to the Nuclear Waste Fund. Exelon Generation paid Power approximately $5.4 million for its portion of the spent fuel storage costs reimbursed by the DOE in 2005 for costs incurred between October&nbsp;1, 2003 and June&nbsp;30, 2005.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In September 2001, Power filed a complaint in the U.S. Court of Federal Claims seeking damages caused by the DOE not taking possession of spent nuclear fuel in 1998. On October&nbsp;14, 2004, an order to show cause was issued regarding whether the U.S. Court of Federal Claims has jurisdiction over the matter. Power responded to this order in November 2004. On January&nbsp;31, 2005, the Judge dismissed the breach-of-contract claims of Power and three other utilities. Power moved for reconsideration in the U.S. Court of Federal Claims and jointly petitioned for permission to appeal the January&nbsp;31, 2005 order to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit. No assurances can be given as to any damage recovery or the ultimate availability of a disposal facility.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Spent Fuel Pool</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The spent fuel pool at each Salem unit has an installed leakage collection system. This system was found to be obstructed at Salem Unit&nbsp;1. Power developed a solution to maintain the design function of the leakage collection system at Salem Unit&nbsp;1 and investigated the existence of any structural degradation that might have been caused by the obstruction. The concrete and reinforcing steel laboratory tests results were completed in March 2006. Test results that have been collected as part of the ongoing testing indicate that no repairs are anticipated. The NRC issued Information Notice 2004-05 in March 2004 concerning this emerging industry issue and Power cannot predict what further actions the NRC may take on this matter.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Elevated concentrations of tritium in the shallow groundwater at Salem Unit&nbsp;1 were detected in early 2003. This information was reported to the NJDEP and the NRC, as required. Power conducted a comprehensive investigation in accordance with NJDEP site remediation regulations to determine the source and extent of the tritium in the groundwater. Power is conducting remedial actions to address the contamination in accordance with a remedial action workplan approved by the NJDEP in November</font></p>
<p align=center>34</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>2004. The remedial actions are expected to be ongoing for several years. The costs necessary to address this on-site groundwater contamination issue are not expected to be material.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Investment Tax Credits (ITC)</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG and&nbsp;PSE&amp;G</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As of June 1999, the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) had issued several private letter rulings (PLRs) that concluded that the refunding of excess deferred tax and ITC balances to utility customers was permitted only over the related assets&#39; regulatory lives, which were terminated upon New Jersey&#39;s electric industry deregulation. Based on this fact, PSEG and PSE&amp;G reversed the deferred tax and ITC liability relating to PSE&amp;G&#39;s generation assets that were transferred to Power, and recorded a $235&nbsp;million reduction of the extraordinary charge in 1999 due to the restructuring of the utility industry in New Jersey. PSE&amp;G was directed by the BPU to seek a&nbsp;PLR from the IRS to determine if the ITC included in the impairment write-down of generation assets could be credited to customers without violating
the tax normalization rules of the Internal Revenue Code. PSE&amp;G filed a&nbsp;PLR request with the IRS in 2002.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On December&nbsp;21, 2005, the Treasury proposed new regulations for comment addressing the normalization of ITC, replacing regulations originally proposed in 2003. The new proposed regulations, if finalized, would not permit retroactive application. Accordingly, the IRS&#39;s conclusions in the above referenced PLRs would continue to remain in effect for all industry deregulations prior to December&nbsp;21, 2005.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On April&nbsp;26, 2006, the BPU issued an order to PSE&amp;G revoking its previous instruction and directing&nbsp;PSE&amp;G to withdraw its request for a PLR by April&nbsp;27, 2006. The BPU asserted that the Treasury&#39;s proposed regulation project was the more appropriate authority to rely upon in deciding the ITC issue.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On May&nbsp;1,
  2006, PSE&amp;G filed a motion for reconsideration with the BPU requesting that
  it modify its April&nbsp;26, 2006 order to PSE&amp;G to withdraw the PLR request.
  On May&nbsp;5, 2006, the BPU denied PSE&amp;G&#39;s motion for reconsideration
  and reiterated its order to withdraw the PLR request. On May&nbsp;8, 2006, PSE&amp;G
  filed a petition with the Appellate Court of New Jersey challenging the BPU&#39;s
  order to withdraw the PLR. The appeal is still pending. On May&nbsp;11, 2006,
  the IRS issued a private letter ruling to PSE&amp;G. The PLR concluded that
  none of the generation ITC could be passed to utility customers without violating
  the normalization rules. While the holding in the PLR is a favorable development
  for PSE&amp;G, the outstanding Treasury regulation project could overturn the
  holding in the PLR if the Treasury were to alter the position set out in the
  December&nbsp;21, 2005 proposed regulations. The issue cannot be fully resolved
  until the final Treasury regulations are issued.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On May&nbsp;16, 2006, the BPU voted in favor of a special investigation and hearing before the BPU concerning&nbsp;PSE&amp;G&#39;s actions leading up to receiving the PLR, specifically its failure to abide by the BPU order to withdraw the request. An order detailing such special investigation has not yet been issued and no investigation has begun. PSE&amp;G cannot predict the outcome of this special investigation.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>While PSE&amp;G cannot predict the outcome of these matters, a requirement to refund such amounts to customers would have a material adverse impact on PSEG&#39;s and PSE&amp;G&#39;s financial condition, results of operations and net cash flows.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>BPU Deferral Audit</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG and PSE&amp;G</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The BPU Energy and Audit Division conducts periodic audits of utilities&#39; deferred balances. A draft Deferral Audit&mdash;Phase&nbsp;II report relating to PSE&amp;G for the 12-month period ended July&nbsp;31, 2003 was released by the consultant to the BPU in April 2005. The draft report addresses PSE&amp;G&#39;s SBC, Market Transition Charge (MTC) and Non-Utility Generation (NUG) deferred balances. The BPU released the report on May&nbsp;13, 2005.</font></p>
<p align=center>35</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>While the consultant to the BPU found that&nbsp;PSE&amp;G&#39;s Phase&nbsp;II deferral balances complied in all material respects with the BPU orders regarding such deferrals, the consultant noted that the BPU Staff had raised certain questions with respect to the reconciliation method&nbsp;PSE&amp;G employed in calculating the overrecovery of its MTC and other charges during the Phase&nbsp;I and Phase&nbsp;II four-year transition period. The amount in dispute is approximately $114 million. PSE&amp;G and the BPU Staff are continuing discussions to resolve these questions and, if a resolution cannot be achieved, a BPU proceeding may be instituted to consider the issues raised. While PSE&amp;G believes the MTC methodology it used was fully litigated and resolved, without exception, by the BPU and other intervening parties
in its previous electric base rate case, deferral audit and deferral proceeding that were approved by the BPU in its order on April&nbsp;22, 2004, and that such order is non-appealable, PSE&amp;G cannot predict the impact of the outcome of any such proceeding.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Leveraged Lease Investments</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Resources faces risks with regard to the creditworthiness of certain lessees that collectively comprise a substantial portion of its investment portfolio. Resources also faces risks related to potential changes in the current accounting and tax treatment of certain investments in leveraged leases.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>From 1996 through 2002, PSEG, through its indirect wholly owned subsidiary, Resources, entered into a number of leveraged lease transactions in the ordinary course of business. Certain of those transactions are similar to a type that the IRS subsequently announced its intention to challenge, and PSEG understands that similar transactions entered into by other companies have been the subject of review and challenge by the IRS. As of each of June&nbsp;30, 2006 and December&nbsp;31, 2005, Resources&#39; total gross investment in such transactions was approximately $1.4 billion. The IRS is presently reviewing the tax returns of PSEG and its subsidiaries for tax years 1997 through 2000, when Resources entered into some of these transactions.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On September&nbsp;27, 2005, the IRS proposed to disallow PSEG&#39;s deductions associated with certain of these leveraged leases which have been designated by the IRS as &ldquo;listed transactions.&rdquo; On July&nbsp;8, 2006, the IRS proposed to disallow deductions associated with another group of these leveraged leases. Other lease transactions within the audit period are still under IRS review. The IRS may propose additional disallowances in the future. If deductions associated with these lease transactions entered into by PSEG are successfully challenged by the IRS, it could have a material adverse impact on PSEG&#39;s and Energy Holdings&#39; financial position, results of operations and net cash flows and could impact future returns on these transactions. PSEG believes that its tax position related to these transactions
is proper based on applicable statutes, regulations and case law and believes that it should prevail with respect to any IRS challenge, although no assurances can be given.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>If the tax benefits associated with all of the listed lease transactions were completely disallowed by the IRS, approximately $717 million of PSEG&#39;s deferred tax liabilities that have been recorded under leveraged lease accounting through June&nbsp;30, 2006 could become currently payable. In addition, interest expense of approximately $106 million, after-tax, and penalties could be assessed. Management assessed the probability of various outcomes to this matter and recorded appropriate reserves in accordance with SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;5 &ldquo;Accounting for Contingencies.&rdquo; Energy Holdings believes that such an outcome is unlikely. However, in the event that such a payment is required, Energy Holdings believes that, assuming certain asset monetizations of its investment portfolio, it has the financial capacity to
meet this potential obligation.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The FASB recently issued additional guidance for leveraged leases. See Note&nbsp;2. Recent Accounting Standards for additional information.</font></p>
<p align=center>36</p>

<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Restructuring Charge</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In June 2005, Power implemented a plan to reduce its Nuclear workforce by approximately 200 positions. The plan included voluntary and involuntary separations offered to both represented and non-represented employees. The major cost associated with the restructuring relates to payments to the employees who were terminated. Power&#39;s $14 million share of the estimated total cost was recorded in 2005, approximately $11 million of which had been paid as of June&nbsp;30, 2006.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Retention Program</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The Retention Program, effective as of December&nbsp;20, 2004, provides for payments to be made to certain key employees of PSEG who remain employed from the date of execution of the Merger Agreement through the date that is&nbsp;90 days after the consummation of the Merger. The amount of a participant&#39;s retention payment may not be less than 40% or more than 150% of the participant&#39;s annual base salary. Retention payments under the Retention Program were not to exceed $10 million in the aggregate.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG paid the first installment, equal to half of a participant&#39;s total retention payment, in December 2005, the first anniversary of the date of execution of the Merger Agreement. The merged company will pay the participants&#39; remaining retention payments within 90&nbsp;days after the consummation of the Merger. In April 2006, the Retention Program was amended to change maximum aggregate payments from $10 million to $15 million. Awards granted after March&nbsp;31, 2006 are to be paid in one installment. No participant whose employment terminates prior to 90 days after the consummation of the Merger, for any reason other than involuntary termination without &ldquo;cause&rdquo;, will receive any retention payment. A participant whose employment is terminated without &ldquo;cause&rdquo;, on or prior to the payment
of the final installment of the retention payment will be treated as if he or she remained employed through the date that is 90&nbsp;days after consummation of the Merger for all purposes under the Retention Program.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Severance Plan</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The Severance Plan provides change in control severance benefits to certain elected officers of PSEG whose employment is terminated without &ldquo;cause&rdquo; or who resign their employment for &ldquo;good reason&rdquo; within two years after a change in control, which would include the consummation of the Merger. Under the Severance Plan, the majority of the participants, if they are terminated without &ldquo;cause&rdquo; or resign employment for &ldquo;good reason,&rdquo; under the terms of the plan, will receive (1)&nbsp;a pro rata bonus based on the participant&#39;s target annual incentive compensation, (2)&nbsp;two times the sum of the participant&#39;s salary and target incentive bonus, (3)&nbsp;accelerated vesting of equity-based awards, (4)&nbsp;a lump sum payment equal to the actuarial equivalent of the participant&#39;s
benefits under all of PSEG&#39;s retirement plans in which the participant participates calculated as though the participant remained employed for two years beyond the date his or her employment terminates less the actuarial equivalent of such benefits on the date his or her employment terminates, (5)&nbsp;two years continued welfare benefits (the first&nbsp;18 months of which will be provided through PSEG-paid COBRA continuation coverage), (6)&nbsp;one year of PSEG-paid outplacement services and (7)&nbsp;vesting of any compensation previously deferred. Under the Severance Plan, five participants will receive the same benefits as the other participants, except that the applicable multiplier for salary and target incentive bonus, retirement plan accruals and continuation of welfare benefits is three years instead of two.</font></p>
<p align=center>37</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Other</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Electroandes</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In July 2005, Electroandes received a notice from Superintendencia Nacional de Administracion Tributaria (SUNAT), the governing tax authority in Peru, claiming past due taxes for 2002 totaling approximately $2 million related to certain interest deductions. Electroandes has taken similar interest deductions subsequent to 2002. The total cumulative estimated potential amount for past due taxes, including associated interest and penalties, is approximately $8 million through June&nbsp;30, 2006. Electroandes believes it has valid legal defenses to these claims, and has filed for an appeal with SUNAT to which it has not yet received a response; however, no assurances can be given regarding the outcome of this matter.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Dhofar Power</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Since commencing operations in Oman in May 2003, Dhofar Power has experienced a number of unplanned service interruptions, including four in the first half of 2004, which resulted from a combination of force majeure events and breaches of general warranties of the contractors that installed equipment at Dhofar Power. Dhofar Power and the Government of Oman have been in a dispute regarding the applicability and extent of any penalties under Dhofar Power&#39;s Concession Agreement arising from these service interruptions. On July&nbsp;14, 2005, the expert engaged by the parties recommended no penalties be assessed for the 2003 service interruptions and agreed with Dhofar Power&#39;s interpretation of the Concession Agreement with respect to the criteria to be utilized in assessing penalties. The Government of Oman has exercised
its right to appeal the expert&#39;s determination to a full arbitration panel. While Dhofar Power believes this matter will be favorably resolved in 2006, no assurances can be given.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Dhofar Power and the Government of Oman are also in disagreement on the basis of the calculation of certain monthly allowances to be paid to compensate Dhofar Power for the capital investment costs associated with the enhancements and extensions of the transmission and distribution system in Salalah. On August&nbsp;24, 2005, the expert engaged by the parties found in favor of Dhofar Power with respect to the criteria to be used in determining the monthly allowances. In the view of Dhofar Power, the Government of Oman has failed to timely exercise its right to appeal the expert&#39;s determination to a full arbitration panel. The Government of Oman has now paid all sums previously due and is continuing to make payments on the basis of Dhofar Power&#39;s calculations, but has not agreed that it is obligated to continue to
pay Dhofar Power on the basis recognized by the expert. Dhofar Power will seek to enforce the expert&#39;s determination that it is entitled to approximately $1 million annually through December 2018 and believes that this matter will be favorably resolved in 2006, although no assurances can be given.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000><a name='note6'>Note&nbsp;6. Risk Management</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The operations of PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings are exposed to market risks from changes in commodity prices, foreign currency exchange rates, interest rates and equity prices that could affect their results of operations and financial conditions. PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings manage exposure to these market risks through their regular operating and financing activities and, when deemed appropriate, hedge these risks through the use of derivative financial instruments. PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings use the term &ldquo;hedge&rdquo; to mean a strategy designed to manage risks of volatility in prices or rate movements on certain assets, liabilities or anticipated transactions and by creating a relationship in which gains or losses on derivative instruments are expected to counterbalance
the gains or losses on the assets, liabilities or anticipated transactions exposed to such</font></p>
<p align=center>38</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>market risks. Each of PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings uses derivative instruments as risk management tools consistent with its respective business plan and prudent business practices.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Derivative Instruments and Hedging Activities</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Power maintains a strategy of entering into positions to optimize the value of its portfolio and reduce earnings volatility of generation assets, gas supply contracts and its electric and gas supply obligations. Power engages in physical and financial transactions in the electricity wholesale markets and executes an overall risk management strategy seeking to mitigate the effects of adverse movements in the fuel and electricity markets. These contracts also involve financial transactions including swaps, options and futures.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Energy Trading Contracts (ETCs)</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Power actively trades energy and energy-related products, including electricity, natural gas, electric capacity, firm transmission rights (FTRs), coal, oil and emission allowances in the spot, forward and futures markets, primarily in&nbsp;PJM, but also in the surrounding region, which extends from Maine to the Carolinas and the Atlantic Coast to Indiana, and natural gas in the producing region.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Power marks to market its derivative ETCs in accordance with SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;133, &ldquo;Accounting for Derivative Instruments and Hedging Activities,&rdquo; as amended (SFAS&nbsp;133), with changes in fair value charged to the Condensed Consolidated Statements of Operations. Wherever possible, fair values for these contracts are obtained from quoted market sources. For contracts where no quoted market exists, modeling techniques are employed using assumptions reflective of current market rates, yield curves and forward prices, as applicable, to interpolate certain prices. The effect of using such modeling techniques is not material to Power&#39;s financial results.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Power routinely enters into exchange-traded futures and options transactions for electricity and natural gas as part of its operations. Generally, such future contracts require a deposit of cash margin, the amount of which is subject to change based on market movement and in accordance with exchange rules. As of June&nbsp;30, 2006, Power had deposited margin of approximately $258 million related to exchange-traded transactions which are margined and monitored separately from physical trading activity.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Commodity Contracts</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The availability and price of energy commodities are subject to fluctuations from factors such as weather, environmental policies, changes in supply and demand, state and federal regulatory policies, market conditions, transmission availability and other events. Power manages its risk of fluctuations of energy price and availability through derivative instruments, such as forward purchase or sale contracts, swaps, options, futures and FTRs.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><u><font color=#000000>Cash Flow Hedges</font></u></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Power uses forward sale and purchase contracts, swaps and FTR contracts to hedge forecasted energy sales from its generation stations and to hedge related load obligations. Power also enters into swaps and futures transactions to hedge the price of fuel to meet its fuel purchase requirements. These derivative transactions are designated and effective as cash flow hedges under SFAS&nbsp;133. As of June&nbsp;30, 2006, the fair value of these hedges was $(634) million. These hedges, along with realized losses on hedges of $15 million retained in Accumulated Other Comprehensive Loss (OCL), resulted in a $(379) million after-tax impact on OCL. As of December&nbsp;31, 2005, the fair value of these hedges was $(951)</font></p>
<p align=center>39</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>million. These hedges, along with realized gains on hedges of $11 million retained in&nbsp;OCL, resulted in a $(558) million after-tax impact on OCL. During the next&nbsp;12 months, $189 million (after-tax) of net unrealized and realized losses on these commodity derivatives is expected to be reclassified to earnings. Approximately $140 million of after-tax unrealized losses on these commodity derivatives in&nbsp;OCL is expected to be reclassified to earnings for the 12&nbsp;months ended June&nbsp;30, 2008. Ineffectiveness associated with these hedges, as defined in SFAS&nbsp;133, was $(8) million at June&nbsp;30, 2006. The expiration date of the longest-dated cash flow hedge is in 2009.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><u><font color=#000000>Other Derivatives</font></u></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Power also enters into certain other contracts that are derivatives, but do not qualify for hedge accounting under SFAS&nbsp;133. Most of these contracts are used for fuel purchases for generation requirements and for electricity purchases for contractual sales obligations. Therefore, the changes in fair market value of these derivative contracts are recorded in Energy Costs or Operating Revenues, as appropriate, on the Condensed Consolidated Statements of Operations. The net fair value of these instruments as of June&nbsp;30, 2006 was $(16) million. The net fair value of these instruments as of December&nbsp;31, 2005 was not material.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Energy Holdings</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><u><font color=#000000>Other Derivatives</font></u></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>TIE enters into electricity forward and capacity sale contracts to sell its&nbsp;2,000&nbsp;MW capacity for portions of the current calendar year and into the daily spot market. TIE also enters into gas purchase contracts to specifically match the generation requirements to support the electricity forward sales contracts. Although these contracts fix the amount of revenue, fuel costs and cash flows, and thereby provide financial stability to TIE, these contracts are, based on their terms, derivatives that do not meet the specific accounting criteria in SFAS&nbsp;133 to qualify for the normal purchases and normal sales exception, or to be designated as a hedge for accounting purposes. As a result, these contracts must be recorded at fair value. The net fair value of the open positions was approximately $8 million and $(7)
million as of June&nbsp;30, 2006 and December&nbsp;31, 2005, respectively.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Interest Rates</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings are subject to the risk of fluctuating interest rates in the normal course of business. PSEG&#39;s policy is to manage interest rate risk through the use of fixed and floating rate debt and interest rate derivatives.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Fair Value Hedges</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>PSEG and Power</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In March 2004, Power issued $250 million of 3.75% Senior Notes due April 2009. PSEG used an interest rate swap to convert Power&#39;s fixed-rate debt into variable-rate debt. The interest rate swap is designated and effective as a fair value hedge. The fair value changes of the interest rate swap are fully offset by the fair value changes in the underlying debt. As of June&nbsp;30, 2006 and December&nbsp;31, 2005, the fair value of the hedge was $(13) million and $(10) million, respectively.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Cash Flow Hedges</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G and Energy Holdings</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G and Energy Holdings use interest rate swaps and other interest rate derivatives to manage their exposures to the variability of cash flows, primarily related to variable-rate debt instruments. The interest rate derivatives used are designated and effective as cash flow hedges. Except</font></p>
<p align=center>40</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>for PSE&amp;G&#39;s cash flow hedges, the fair value changes of these derivatives are initially recorded in&nbsp;OCL. As of June&nbsp;30, 2006, the fair value of these cash flow hedges was $2 million, including $(3) million and $5 million at&nbsp;PSE&amp;G and Energy Holdings, respectively. As of December&nbsp;31, 2005, the fair value of these cash flow hedges was $(17) million, including $(11) million and $(6) million at PSE&amp;G and Energy Holdings, respectively. The $(3) million and $(11) million at PSE&amp;G as of June&nbsp;30, 2006 and December&nbsp;31, 2005, respectively, is not included in OCL, as it is deferred as a Regulatory Asset and is expected to be recovered from PSE&amp;G&#39;s customers. During the next twelve months, $1 million of unrealized losses (net of taxes) on interest rate derivatives in OCL is expected to be reclassified to earnings
at PSEG, PSE&amp;G and Energy Holdings. As of June&nbsp;30, 2006, there was essentially no hedge ineffectiveness associated with these hedges. The fair value amounts above as of December&nbsp;31, 2005 do not include approximately $(60) million for the cash flow hedges at Elcho, which had been reclassified into Discontinued Operations.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Other Derivatives</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Energy Holdings</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As of June&nbsp;30, 2006, Energy Holdings had no cross-currency interest rate swaps where changes in fair value of such swaps are recorded in Income from Equity Method Investments on the Condensed Consolidated Statements of Operations. The fair value of these swaps at December&nbsp;31, 2005 was approximately $(2) million.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Foreign Currencies</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Global is exposed to foreign currency risk and other foreign operations risk that arise from investments in foreign subsidiaries and affiliates. A key component of its risks is that some of its foreign subsidiaries and affiliates have functional currencies other than the consolidated reporting currency, the U.S. Dollar. Additionally, Global and certain of its foreign subsidiaries and affiliates have entered into monetary obligations and maintain receipts/receivables in U.S. Dollars or currencies other than their own functional currencies. Global, a U.S. Dollar functional currency entity, is primarily exposed to changes in the Euro, the Peruvian Nuevo Sol and the Chilean Peso. Changes in valuation of these currencies can impact the value of Global&#39;s investments. Global has attempted to limit potential foreign exchange
exposure by entering into revenue contracts that adjust for changes in foreign exchange rates. Global also uses foreign currency forward, swap and option agreements to manage risk related to certain foreign currency fluctuations.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As of June&nbsp;30, 2006, the net cumulative foreign currency revaluations have increased the total amount of Global&#39;s Member&#39;s Equity by $109&nbsp;million.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In November and December 2005, Energy Holdings purchased foreign currency options in order to hedge the majority of its 2006 expected earnings denominated in Brazilian Real, Chilean Pesos and Peruvian Nuevo Soles. These options are not considered hedges for accounting purposes under SFAS&nbsp;133 and, as a result, changes in their fair value are recorded directly to earnings. Energy Holdings terminated its remaining Brazilian Real options on June&nbsp;28, 2006. The fair value of the options outstanding at June&nbsp;30, 2006 and December&nbsp;31, 2005 was approximately $1 million and $2 million, respectively.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Hedges of Net Investments in Foreign Operations</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In March 2004 and April 2004, Energy Holdings entered into four cross-currency interest rate swap agreements. The swaps are designed to hedge the net investment in a foreign subsidiary associated with the exposure to the U.S. Dollar to Chilean Peso exchange rate. The fair value of the cross-currency swaps was $(24) million and $(33) million as of June&nbsp;30, 2006 and December&nbsp;31, 2005, respectively. The</font></p>
<p align=center>41</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>change in fair value is recorded net of tax in Cumulative Translation Adjustment within OCL. As a result, Energy Holdings&#39; Member&#39;s Equity was reduced by $21 million as of June&nbsp;30, 2006.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000><a name='note7'>Note&nbsp;7. Comprehensive Income (Loss), Net of Tax</a></font></b></p>

<p align=center>42</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000><a name='note8'>Note&nbsp;8. Changes in Capitalization</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>PSEG</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>During the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2006, PSEG issued approximately 523,000 shares of its common stock under its Dividend Reinvestment Program and Employee Stock Purchase Program for approximately $34 million.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In February 2006, PSEG redeemed $154 million of its Subordinated Debentures underlying $150 million of Enterprise Capital Trust&nbsp;II, Floating Rate Capital Securities and its common equity investment in the trust.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On June&nbsp;23, 2006, PSE&amp;G repaid at maturity $174 million of its Floating Rate Series&nbsp;A First and Refunding Mortgage Bonds.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On March&nbsp;1, 2006, PSE&amp;G repaid at maturity $148 million of its&nbsp;6.75% Series&nbsp;UU First and Refunding Mortgage Bonds.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In June 2006 and March 2006, Transition Funding repaid approximately $35 million and $36 million, respectively, of its transition bonds</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In June 2006, PSE&amp;G Transition Funding&nbsp;II LLC (Transition Funding&nbsp;II) repaid approximately $3 million of its transition bonds.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In April 2006, Power repaid at maturity $500 million of its&nbsp;6.875% Senior Notes.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In January 2006, Energy Holdings redeemed $309 million of its&nbsp;7.75% Senior Notes due in 2007.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On February&nbsp;17, 2006, the maturity of the Odessa&ndash;Ector Power Partners, L.P (Odessa) debt was extended to December&nbsp;31, 2009. Interest on the debt is based on a spread (currently&nbsp;2.25%) above LIBOR. On September&nbsp;29, 2006, an interest rate swap will take effect which will convert the floating LIBOR interest rate on approximately&nbsp;80% of Odessa&#39;s debt to a fixed rate of&nbsp;5.4275% through December&nbsp;31, 2009.</font></p>
<p align=center>43</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>

<tr bgcolor=#ffffff>

<td align=right valign=top><font color=#000000>(B)</font></td>
<td align=left valign=bottom nowrap>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=bottom><font color=#000000>PSEG&#39;s other activities include amounts applicable to PSEG (as parent company), and intercompany eliminations, primarily relating to intercompany transactions between Power and&nbsp;PSE&amp;G. No gains or losses are recorded on any intercompany transactions; rather, all intercompany transactions are at cost or, in the case of the&nbsp;BGS and BGSS contracts between Power and&nbsp;PSE&amp;G, at rates prescribed by the&nbsp;BPU. For a further discussion of the intercompany transactions between Power and&nbsp;PSE&amp;G, see Note&nbsp;13. Related-Party Transactions. The net losses primarily relate to financing and certain administrative and general costs at PSEG, as parent company.</font></td></tr>
</table>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000><a name='Note12'>Note 12. Stock-Based Compensation</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>PSEG</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As approved at the Annual Meeting of Stockholders in 2004, PSEG&#39;s 2004 Long-Term Incentive Plan (2004 LTIP) replaced prior Long-Term Incentive Plans (the 1989 LTIP and 2001 LTIP). The 2004 LTIP is a broad-based equity compensation program that provides for grants of various long-term incentive compensation awards, such as stock options, stock appreciation rights, performance shares, restricted stock, cash awards or any combination thereof. The types of long-term incentive awards that have been granted and remain outstanding under the LTIPs are non-qualified options to purchase shares of PSEG&#39;s common stock, restricted stock awards and performance unit awards. However, since 2004, only restricted stock has been granted.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The 2004 LTIP currently provides for the issuance of equity awards with respect to approximately&nbsp;13.0 million shares of common stock. As of June&nbsp;30, 2006, there were&nbsp;11.8 million shares available for future awards under the 2004 LTIP.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Stock Options</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Under the 2004 LTIP, non-qualified options to acquire shares of PSEG common stock may be granted to officers and other key employees of PSEG and its subsidiaries selected by the Organization and Compensation Committee of PSEG&#39;s Board of Directors, the plan&#39;s administrative committee (Committee). Option awards are granted with an exercise price equal to the market price of PSEG&#39;s common stock at the grant date. The options generally vest based on three to five years of continuous service. Vesting schedules may be accelerated upon the occurrence of certain events, such as a change-in-control, retirement, death or disability. Options are exercisable over a period of time designated by the Committee (but not prior to one year or longer than&nbsp;10 years from the date of grant) and are subject to such other terms
and conditions as the Committee determines. Payment by option holders upon exercise of an option may be made in cash or, with the consent of the Committee, by delivering previously acquired shares of PSEG common stock.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG purchases shares on the open market to meet the exercise requirements of stock options.</font></p>
<p align=center>48</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Restricted Stock</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Under the 2004 LTIP, PSEG has granted restricted stock awards to officers and other key employees. These shares are subject to risk of forfeiture until vested by continued employment. Restricted stock generally vests annually over three years, but are considered outstanding at the time of grant, as the recipients are entitled to dividends and voting rights. Vesting may be accelerated upon certain events, such as change in control (unless substituted with an equity award of equal value), retirement, death or disability.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In addition, from 1998 to 2001, PSEG granted&nbsp;210,000 shares of restricted stock to a key executive, which are subject to risk of forfeiture until vested by continued employment. The shares vest on a staggered schedule through March 2007.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG issues restricted stock from treasury stock.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Performance Units</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Under the 2004 LTIP, performance units were granted to certain key executives, which provide for payment in shares of PSEG common stock based on achievement of certain financial goals over the three-year period from 2004 through 2006. The payout varies from&nbsp;0% to&nbsp;200% of the number of performance units granted depending on PSEG&#39;s performance compared to the performance of other companies in the Dow Jones Utilities Index. The performance units are credited with dividend equivalents in an amount equal to dividends paid on PSEG common stock up until January&nbsp;1, 2007. Vesting may be accelerated upon certain events such as change in control, retirement, death or disability.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Stock-Based Compensation</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Effective January&nbsp;1, 2006, PSEG adopted SFAS 123R. See Note&nbsp;2. Recent Accounting Standards for a description of the adoption of SFAS 123R. As a result, all outstanding unvested stock options as of January&nbsp;1, 2006 are being expensed based on their grant date fair values, which were determined using the Black-Scholes option-pricing model. Stock option awards are expensed on a tranche-specific basis over the requisite service period of the award. Ultimately, compensation expense for stock options is recognized for awards that vest.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Prior to the adoption of SFAS 123R, PSEG recognized compensation expense for restricted stock over the vesting period based on the grant date fair market value of the shares. PSEG will continue to recognize compensation expense over the vesting term.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Also prior to the adoption of SFAS 123R, PSEG recognized compensation expense for performance units. The fair value of each performance unit was based on the grant date fair value of PSEG stock. The accrual of compensation cost was based on the probable achievement of the performance conditions, which result in a payout from&nbsp;0% to&nbsp;200% of the initial grant. The current accrual is estimated at&nbsp;100% of the original grant. The accrual is adjusted for subsequent changes in the estimated or actual outcome.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Compensation cost from options, restricted stock and performance units is included in Operation and Maintenance Expense in PSEG&#39;s Condensed Consolidated Statements of Operations and amounted to approximately $3.3 million and $1.9 million for the quarters ended June&nbsp;30, 2006 and 2005, respectively, and approximately $6.6 million and $3.5 million for the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2006 and 2005, respectively. The total income tax benefit recognized in PSEG&#39;s Condensed Consolidated Statements of Operations was approximately $1.4 million and $0.8 million for the quarters ended June&nbsp;30, 2006 and 2005, respectively, and approximately $2.7 million and $1.4 million for the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2006 and 2005, respectively. Compensation cost capitalized as part of property, plant and equipment was
less than $0.1 million for each of the quarters ended June&nbsp;30, 2006 and 2005 and approximately $0.1 million for each of the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2006 and 2005. Of the total compensation cost for the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2006, approximately $0.6 million, or $0.3 million after-tax, related to the adoption of SFAS 123R, which was primarily due to expensing stock options for</font></p>
<p align=center>49</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>the first time. There was no impact on basic and diluted earnings per share from the implementation of SFAS 123R because there were a relatively small number of outstanding unvested stock options as of the implementation date.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Prior to the adoption of SFAS 123R, PSEG presented all tax benefits for deductions resulting from the exercise of share-based compensation as operating cash flows in the Condensed Consolidated Statement of Cash Flows. SFAS 123R requires the benefits of tax deductions in excess of the taxes expensed on recognized compensation cost to be reported as financing cash flows. There was approximately $18 million of excess tax benefits included as a financing cash inflow in the June&nbsp;30, 2006 Condensed Consolidated Statements of Cash Flow. Total cash flow will remain unchanged from what would have been reported under prior accounting rules.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The following table illustrates the effect on net income and earnings per share if PSEG had applied the fair value recognition provisions of SFAS 123R for the quarter and six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2005.</font></p>

<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Prior to the adoption of SFAS 123R, PSEG recognized the compensation cost of stock based awards issued to retirement eligible employees that fully or partially vest upon an employee&#39;s retirement over the nominal vesting period of performance, and recognized any remaining compensation cost at the date of retirement. In accordance with SFAS 123R, PSEG recognizes compensation cost of awards issued after January&nbsp;1, 2006 over the shorter of the original vesting period or the period beginning on the date of grant and ending on the date an individual is retirement eligible and the award vests.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>There were no options granted during 2005 or 2006. Changes in stock options for the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2006 are summarized as follows:</font></p>

<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The intrinsic value of options is the difference between the current market price and the exercise price. The total intrinsic value of options exercised during the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2006 and 2005</font></p>
<p align=center>50</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>was approximately $43.1 million and $36.2 million, respectively. During the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2006 and 2005, cash received from stock options exercised was approximately $65.0 million and $82.5 million, respectively. The tax benefit realized from stock options exercised during the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2006 and 2005 was approximately $17.6 million and $14.8 million, respectively.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As of June&nbsp;30, 2006, there was approximately $0.7 million of unrecognized compensation cost related to stock options, which is expected to be recognized over a weighted average period of seven months.</font></p>

<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The weighted average grant date fair value per share was $51.91 for restricted stock awards granted during the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2005.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The total intrinsic value of restricted stock vested during the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2006 was approximately $6.1 million. No restricted shares vested during the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2005.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As of June&nbsp;30, 2006, there was approximately $19.1 million of unrecognized compensation cost related to restricted stock, which is expected to be recognized over a weighted average period of&nbsp;2.1 years.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Performance Units Information</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As of June&nbsp;30, 2006, 82,700 performance units were outstanding and unvested, net of&nbsp;900 units forfeited in the six-month period then ended. Approximately&nbsp;7,900 dividend equivalents had accrued on these performance units. The grant date fair value of the performance units is $42.75 per unit.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Assuming performance units are paid out at the&nbsp;100% performance level, the total intrinsic value of performance units outstanding at June&nbsp;30, 2006 is approximately $6.0 million.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As of June&nbsp;30, 2006, there was approximately $0.7 million of unrecognized compensation cost related to performance units, which is expected to be recognized over the next six months.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Outside Directors</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>During 2006, each director who was not an officer of PSEG or its subsidiaries and affiliates will be paid an annual retainer of $50,000. Pursuant to the Compensation Plan for Outside Directors, a certain percentage, currently&nbsp;50%, of the annual retainer is paid in PSEG common stock.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG also maintains a Stock Plan for Outside Directors (Stock Plan) pursuant to which directors of PSEG who are not employees of PSEG or its subsidiaries receive a restricted stock award, currently&nbsp;1,000 shares per year, for each year of service as a director. The restrictions on the stock granted under the Stock Plan provide that the shares are subject to forfeiture if the director leaves service at any time prior to the Annual Meeting of Stockholders following his or her 70th birthday. This restriction would be deemed to have been satisfied if the director&#39;s service were terminated after a &ldquo;change in control&rdquo; as defined in the Stock Plan or if the director were to die in office. PSEG also has the ability to waive this restriction for good cause shown. Restricted stock may not be sold or otherwise
transferred prior to the lapse of the restrictions. Dividends on shares held subject to restrictions are paid directly to the director who has the right to vote the shares. The fair value of these shares is recorded as</font></p>
<p align=center>51</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>compensation expense in the Condensed Consolidated Statements of Operations. Compensation expense for the Stock Plan was less than $0.2 million for each of the quarters ended June&nbsp;30, 2006 and 2005 and approximately $0.3 million for each of the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2006 and 2005.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Employee Stock Purchase Plan</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG maintains an employee stock purchase plan for all eligible employees of PSEG and its subsidiaries. Under the plan, shares of PSEG common stock may be purchased at&nbsp;95% of the fair market value through payroll deductions. Employees may purchase shares having a value not exceeding&nbsp;10% of their base pay. During the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2006 and 2005, employees purchased&nbsp;21,794 and&nbsp;27,772 shares at an average price of $60.77 and $51.90 per share, respectively. As of June&nbsp;30, 2006, 1.9 million shares were available for future issuance under this plan.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000><a name='note13'></font><font color=#000000>Note&nbsp;13. Related-Party Transactions</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The majority of the following discussion relates to intercompany transactions, which are eliminated during the consolidation process in accordance with GAAP.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>BGS and BGSS Contracts</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G and Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G has entered into a requirements contract with Power under which Power provides the gas supply services needed to meet&nbsp;PSE&amp;G&#39;s BGSS and other contractual requirements through March 2007. Power has also entered into contracts to supply energy, capacity and ancillary services to&nbsp;PSE&amp;G through the&nbsp;BGS auction process.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The amounts which Power charged to&nbsp;PSE&amp;G for&nbsp;BGS and BGSS are presented below:</font></p>
<table width=100% cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 border=0><tr bgcolor=#ffffff>

<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As of June&nbsp;30, 2006 and December&nbsp;31, 2005, Power had net receivables from&nbsp;PSE&amp;G of approximately $164 million and $454 million, respectively, primarily related to the&nbsp;BGS and BGSS contracts. These transactions were properly recognized on each company&#39;s stand-alone financial statements and were eliminated when preparing PSEG&#39;s Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In addition, as of June&nbsp;30, 2006 and December&nbsp;31, 2005, PSE&amp;G had a payable to Power of approximately $55 million and a receivable of approximately $152 million, respectively, related to gas supply hedges Power entered into for BGSS.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Services</font></b></p>

In addition, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings have other payables to Services, including amounts related to certain common costs, such as pension and OPEB costs, which Services pays on behalf of</font></p>

<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Affiliate Loans and Advances</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG and Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As of June&nbsp;30, 2006 and December&nbsp;31, 2005, Power had a demand note payable to PSEG of approximately $145 million and $202 million, respectively, for short-term funding needs.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As of June&nbsp;30, 2006, Energy Holdings had a demand note receivable of $258 million due from PSEG and a term note receivable of $450 million due on September&nbsp;30, 2006 from PSEG. As of December&nbsp;31, 2005, Energy Holdings had a demand note receivable due from PSEG of $409 million. These notes reflect the investment of Energy Holdings&#39; excess cash with PSEG.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G and Services</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As of each of June&nbsp;30, 2006 and December&nbsp;31, 2005, PSE&amp;G had advanced working capital to Services of approximately $33 million. This amount is included in Other Noncurrent Assets on&nbsp;PSE&amp;G&#39;s Condensed Consolidated Balance Sheets.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Power and Services</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As of each of June&nbsp;30, 2006 and December&nbsp;31, 2005, Power had advanced working capital to Services of approximately $17 million. This amount is included in Other Noncurrent Assets on Power&#39;s Condensed Consolidated Balance Sheets.</font></p>

<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Other</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG and&nbsp;PSE&amp;G</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As of June&nbsp;30, 2006 and December&nbsp;31, 2005, PSE&amp;G had net receivables from PSEG of approximately $6 million related to amounts that PSEG had collected on&nbsp;PSE&amp;G&#39;s behalf.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG and Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As of June&nbsp;30, 2006 and December&nbsp;31, 2005, Power had net receivables from PSEG of approximately $1 million related to amounts that PSEG had collected on Power&#39;s behalf.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As of June&nbsp;30, 2006 and December&nbsp;31, 2005, Energy Holdings had net receivables from PSEG of approximately $2 million and $1 million, respectively, primarily for interest due on the demand note receivable from PSEG.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Energy Holdings and&nbsp;PSE&amp;G</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As of June&nbsp;30, 2006 and December&nbsp;31, 2005, Energy Holdings had a receivable of approximately $2 million and $3 million, respectively, related to efficiency incentive initiatives performed for&nbsp;PSE&amp;G&#39;s customers. Energy Holdings recorded revenues for such services of approximately $3 million and $6&nbsp;million for the quarters ended June&nbsp;30, 2006 and 2005, respectively, and approximately $7 million and $11 million for the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2006 and 2005, respectively.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000><a name='note14'></font><font color=#000000>Note&nbsp;14. Guarantees of Debt</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Each series of Power&#39;s Senior Notes and Pollution Control Notes is fully and unconditionally and jointly and severally guaranteed by Fossil, Nuclear and&nbsp;ER&amp;T. The following table presents condensed financial information for the guarantor subsidiaries, as well as Power&#39;s non-guarantor subsidiaries.</font></p>
<table width=100% cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 border=0><tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=center valign=bottom colspan=3><b><font color=#000000><small>Power<br>
<hr color=#000000 noshade size=1></small></font></b></td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=center valign=bottom colspan=3><b><font color=#000000><small>Guarantor<br>
Subsidiaries<br>
<hr color=#000000 noshade size=1></small></font></b></td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=center valign=bottom colspan=3><b><font color=#000000><small>Other<br>
Subsidiaries<br>
<hr color=#000000 noshade size=1></small></font></b></td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=center valign=bottom colspan=3><b><font color=#000000><small>Consolidating<br>
Adjustments<br>
<hr color=#000000 noshade size=1></small></font></b></td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=center valign=bottom colspan=3><b><font color=#000000><small>Consolidated<br>
Total<br>
<hr color=#000000 noshade size=1></small></font></b></td></tr>
<tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
