<p align=center>56</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000><a name='management'>ITEM&nbsp;2. MANAGEMENT&#39;S DISCUSSION&nbsp;AND ANALYSIS&nbsp;OF FINANCIAL<br>
CONDITION&nbsp;AND RESULTS&nbsp;OF OPERATIONS (MD&amp;A)</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Following are the significant changes in or additions to information reported in the 2005 Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K affecting the consolidated financial condition and the results of operations. This discussion refers to the Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements (Statements) and the related Notes to Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements (Notes) and should be read in conjunction with such Statements and Notes.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>This combined&nbsp;MD&amp;A is separately filed by Public Service Enterprise Group Incorporated (PSEG), Public Service Electric and Gas Company (PSE&amp;G), PSEG Power&nbsp;LLC (Power), and PSEG Energy Holdings&nbsp;L.L.C. (Energy Holdings). Information contained herein relating to any individual company is filed by such company on its own behalf. PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings each make representations only as to itself and make no representations as to any other company.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000><a name='pending'>PENDING MERGER</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On December&nbsp;20, 2004, PSEG entered into an agreement and plan of merger (Merger Agreement) with Exelon Corporation (Exelon), a public utility holding company headquartered in Chicago, Illinois, whereby PSEG will be merged with and into Exelon (Merger). Under the terms of the Merger Agreement, upon closing of the Merger, each share of PSEG Common Stock will be converted into&nbsp;1.225 shares of Exelon Common Stock.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The Merger Agreement has been unanimously approved by both companies&#39; Boards of Directors. On July&nbsp;19, 2005, shareholders of PSEG voted to approve the Merger and on July&nbsp;22, 2005, shareholders of Exelon voted to approve the issuance of common shares to PSEG shareholders to effect the Merger.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG and Exelon have obtained all regulatory approvals from the principal governmental authorities involved to complete the Merger, except the New Jersey Board of Public Utilities (BPU).</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On June&nbsp;1, 2006, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission approved the Merger.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On June&nbsp;22, 2006, Exelon and PSEG reached an agreement with the&nbsp;U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ), which resolved all competition issues reviewed by the&nbsp;DOJ in connection with the Merger. The terms of the&nbsp;DOJ agreement require the merged company to enter into agreements within&nbsp;150 days after the Merger closes to sell the following six fossil fuel-fired electric generating stations with a total capacity of approximately&nbsp;5,600 megawatts (MW) and gives the&nbsp;DOJ approval rights over the buyers to assure a competitive market after the divestiture:</font></p>
<table width=100% cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 border=0><tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=top colspan=3><u><font color=#000000>Owned by PSEG</font></u></td></tr>
<tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=left valign=top nowrap>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>&bull;</font></td>
<td align=left valign=top nowrap>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>Linden, a&nbsp;1,544&nbsp;MW combined cycle natural gas and peaking (gas/oil) facility in Linden, New&nbsp;Jersey</font></td></tr>
<tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=left valign=top nowrap>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>&bull;</font></td>
<td align=left valign=top nowrap>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>Mercer, a&nbsp;777 MW coal-and natural gas/oil-fired facility in Hamilton, New Jersey</font></td></tr>
<tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=left valign=top nowrap>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>&bull;</font></td>
<td align=left valign=top nowrap>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>Hudson, a&nbsp;991 MW coal-and natural gas-fired facility in Woodbridge, New Jersey</font></td></tr>
<tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=left valign=top nowrap>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>&bull;</font></td>
<td align=left valign=top nowrap>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>Sewaren Units&nbsp;1-4, a&nbsp;452 MW natural gas/oil steam facility in Woodbridge, New Jersey</font></td></tr>
<tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=top colspan=3><u><font color=#000000>Owned by Exelon</font></u></td></tr>
<tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=left valign=top nowrap>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>&bull;</font></td>
<td align=left valign=top nowrap>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>Eddystone, a&nbsp;1,408&nbsp;MW coal-fired, mid-merit (oil/gas) and peaking (oil) facility in Eddystone, Pennsylvania</font></td></tr>
<tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=left valign=top nowrap>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>&bull;</font></td>
<td align=left valign=top nowrap>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>Cromby, a&nbsp;345 MW coal-and natural gas/oil-fired facility in Phoenixville, Pennsylvania</font></td></tr>
</table>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Also under the terms of the&nbsp;DOJ agreement, for a period of&nbsp;10 years following the Merger, the merged company will be required to obtain&nbsp;DOJ&#39;s prior approval before acquiring or obtaining control of any existing power plants in the mid-Atlantic region. The proposed settlement and the&nbsp;DOJ&#39;s competitive impact statement are subject to public written comment for a period of&nbsp;60 days and approval of the&nbsp;U.S. District Court, but closing of the Merger is not contingent upon such approval.</font></p>
<p align=center>57</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The fossil power plant divestiture required by the settlement with the&nbsp;DOJ will satisfy the requirements imposed by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) in its June 2005 order approving the Merger to divest fossil generation. The virtual nuclear divestiture approved by FERC continues to be an obligation of the merged company, even though it is not required by the&nbsp;DOJ settlement. The divestitures will be required only if the Merger closes.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In New Jersey,
  the&nbsp;BPU issued an order on June&nbsp;20, 2005, requiring Exelon and PSEG
  to prove that positive benefits flow to&nbsp;PSE&amp;G&#39;s customers and the
  State of New Jersey as a result of the Merger, and that, at a minimum, there
  would be no adverse impact to competition, employees or reliability due to the
  Merger. Exelon and&nbsp;PSE&amp;G are negotiating with the&nbsp;BPU Staff and
  other interested parties in an effort to reach a settlement of the Merger proceeding.
  Exelon and&nbsp;PSE&amp;G recently made a materially enhanced settlement offer
  in the ongoing discussions, which they believe provides substantial positive
  benefits to customers and the State of New Jersey. The comprehensive offer provides
  cash to be used for a variety of customer and state benefits, primarily immediate
  rate reductions, rate concessions and other terms that are significantly greater
  than originally offered. As a result of this offer,
  PSE&amp;G&#39;s earnings and cash flow would be materially reduced in the near
  term. PSEG and Exelon have also indicated that it is essential to reach a settlement
  promptly in order to complete the transaction. If a settlement is reached, it
  would need to be reviewed by the Administrative Law Judge (ALJ) and would need
  to be approved by the&nbsp;BPU. Although PSEG believes
  that this process can be completed in time to allow the merger to close in the
  third quarter of 2006, there is currently no established timetable for&nbsp;BPU
  action on the merger. As a result, it is possible that the closing could slip
  into the fourth quarter.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The regulatory and political developments in Illinois pertaining to Exelon&#39;s rates and operations could also have an effect on the timing or closing conditions of the Merger.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The final decision on whether to proceed with the Merger will rest with the Boards of both PSEG and Exelon after the terms and conditions of all regulatory requirements are known. The Merger Agreement provides that if the Merger was not consummated by June&nbsp;20, 2006, either party can terminate the Merger Agreement without penalty. Neither Exelon nor PSEG has taken any action to terminate the Merger Agreement or extend the June&nbsp;20, 2006 date in the Merger Agreement.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Although PSEG and Exelon believe that the expectations as to timing for the closing of the Merger described above are reasonable, no assurances can be given as to the timing of the receipt of the&nbsp;BPU approval, that the approval will be received or that potential conditions required by the&nbsp;BPU will be acceptable to the parties or not have materially adverse conditions.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG is committed to maintaining a viable stand-alone business strategy in the event the Merger does not close. In the event that the Merger Agreement is terminated prior to closing, Management believes PSEG will continue to operate successfully on a stand-alone basis; however, inability to close the Merger could have an adverse impact on PSEG&#39;s stock price, PSEG&#39;s, PSE&amp;G&#39;s and Power&#39;s credit ratings and the markets for their respective securities and could materially and adversely impact the financial condition, results of operations and cash flows of PSEG, PSE&amp;G and Power. As a condition of maintaining existing credit ratings, it could be necessary for PSEG, PSE&amp;G and Power to reduce debt and/or obtain additional equity. It is not possible to predict whether the market prices for PSEG common
stock may be adversely affected by the dilutive effect of any such additional equity. It is also not possible to predict the impact on any of the securities of PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings of investor perception of the respective near-term prospects of those companies, including Power&#39;s ability to maintain the current level of nuclear operating performance if PSEG is unable to extend the current Nuclear Operating Services Contract with Exelon (see Note&nbsp;5. Commitments and Contingent Liabilities), and the effect on operations of PSEG&#39;s current significantly reduced staffing.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000><a name='overview'>OVERVIEW&nbsp;OF 2006&nbsp;AND FUTURE OUTLOOK</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>PSEG</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG&#39;s business consists of four reportable segments, which are&nbsp;PSE&amp;G, Power and the two direct subsidiaries of Energy Holdings: PSEG Global&nbsp;L.L.C. (Global) and PSEG Resources&nbsp;L.L.C. (Resources). The following is a discussion of the markets in which PSEG and its subsidiaries compete, the corporate strategy for the conduct of PSEG&#39;s businesses within these markets, significant events that have occurred during the first half of 2006 and expectations for the full year 2006 and beyond.</font></p>
<p align=center>58</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>For the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2006, PSEG had Net Income of $412 million, or $1.64 per share, discussed below in Results of Operations. Included in Net Income is an after-tax gain of $228 million, or $0.90 per share, related to the sale of two generating stations in Poland, which is included in Income from Discontinued Operations and an after-tax loss of approximately $177 million, or $0.70 per share, related to the sale of Rio Grande Energia&nbsp;S.A. (RGE), an electric distribution company in Brazil. The loss at&nbsp;RGE primarily related to devaluation of the Brazilian Real subsequent to Global&#39;s acquisition of its interests in&nbsp;RGE in 1997. Also included in Net Income for the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2006 are Merger-related costs of approximately $8 million, after-tax, or $0.03 per share. In order
to provide a more consistent and comparable measure of the performance of its businesses to help shareholders understand performance trends, earnings projections for PSEG and its subsidiaries consist of projected Income from Continuing Operations, excluding impacts from asset sales and Merger-related costs and do not contemplate any potential impacts from mark-to-market (MTM) accounting. Excluding such items, PSEG continues to project earnings for 2006 to range from $3.45 to $3.75 per share, although the range of expected earnings from each of&nbsp;PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings has been revised from earlier announced projections. PSE&amp;G&#39;s guidance has decreased due to the prolonged lack of rate relief; Power&#39;s guidance has increased due to improved operations and stronger energy markets and Energy Holdings&#39; guidance has increased due to a strong Texas market. The projections
for 2006 also include $60 million to $70 million of expenses at the PSEG parent level, primarily for financing costs. In addition, PSEG anticipates earnings per share growth to be in excess of 10% per year for 2007 and&nbsp;2008.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG expects operating cash flows in 2006 and beyond to be sufficient to meet capital needs and dividend requirements and may employ any excess cash to reduce debt, invest in its businesses, increase dividends or, in the longer term, repurchase shares. On July&nbsp;18, 2006, PSEG&#39;s Board of Directors approved a common stock dividend of $0.57 per share for the third quarter of 2006, reflecting an indicated annual dividend rate of $2.28 per share.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Several key factors that will drive PSEG&#39;s future success are energy, capacity and fuel prices, performance of Power&#39;s generating facilities, PSE&amp;G&#39;s ability to maintain a reasonable rate of return under its regulated rate structure and the stability of international economies for Energy Holdings.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G operates as an electric and gas public utility in New Jersey under cost-based regulation by the&nbsp;BPU for its distribution operations and by the FERC for its electric transmission and wholesale sales operations. Consequently, PSE&amp;G&#39;s earnings are largely determined by the regulation of its rates by those agencies.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Commodity costs continue to put upward pressure on customer charges and have contributed to flat electric delivery sales and a decline in year-over-year gas delivery sales. On June&nbsp;1, 2006, new electric Basic Generation Service (BGS)-Fixed Price (FP) rates went into effect and residential customers&#39; bills are expected to increase by approximately&nbsp;14%. While gas prices have stabilized, the current cost to a residential Basic Gas Supply Service (BGSS) customer is approximately&nbsp;42% higher than a year ago. The&nbsp;1% increase in the New Jersey sales tax on July&nbsp;15, 2006 will also increase customer charges. Since sales tax and commodity price increases are passed through to customers, they do not increase&nbsp;PSE&amp;G&#39;s earnings but they can have a negative impact on&nbsp;PSE&amp;G&#39;s earnings
if they result in reduced customer demand.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On September&nbsp;30, 2005, PSE&amp;G filed a petition with the&nbsp;BPU seeking a $133 million increase in annual gas base rates, an overall&nbsp;3.78% increase. PSE&amp;G expects any rate relief from this filing to begin late in 2006 or early in 2007. The filing was based on a test year that ended nine months ago. Even if the increase were granted in full, PSE&amp;G would not achieve the requested&nbsp;11% return on equity due to sales declines and expense changes.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G also has pending a request for a $64 million electric rate increase resulting from the expiration of a depreciation rate credit as of December 2005. PSE&amp;G expects that final resolution of this case will likely be determined later in 2006.</font></p>
<p align=center>59</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Action on&nbsp;PSE&amp;G&#39;s recent filings, including the excess depreciation rate credit and the gas base rate case, has been subject to ongoing delays. Until the Merger is resolved with the&nbsp;BPU, final resolution of&nbsp;PSE&amp;G&#39;s rate requests is not expected.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>For the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2006, PSE&amp;G had Net Income of $112 million. As a result of the substantial decline in earnings at&nbsp;PSE&amp;G as compared to 2005 and the continued delay in decisions for the current gas base rate case and the elimination of the $64 million electric depreciation rate credit (approximately $68 million based on current sales volumes), PSE&amp;G has lowered its earnings guidance from a range of $315 million to $335 million to a range of $250 million to $270 million in 2006. As disclosed previously, these amounts exclude any Merger-related costs.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The risks to&nbsp;PSE&amp;G&#39;s business generally relate to the treatment of the various rate and other issues by the state and federal regulatory agencies, specifically the&nbsp;BPU and FERC. In 2006 and beyond, PSE&amp;G&#39;s success will depend, in part, on its ability to maintain a reasonable rate of return, continue cost containment initiatives, maintain system reliability and safety levels and continued recovery, with an adequate return, of the regulatory assets it has deferred and the investments it plans to make in its electric and gas transmission and distribution system. Since&nbsp;PSE&amp;G earns no margin on the commodity portion of its electric and gas sales through tariff agreements, there is no anticipated commodity price volatility for&nbsp;PSE&amp;G.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Power is an electric generation and wholesale energy marketing and trading company that is focused on a generation market extending from Maine to the Carolinas and the Atlantic Coast to Indiana. Power&#39;s principal operating subsidiaries, PSEG Fossil&nbsp;LLC (Fossil), PSEG Nuclear&nbsp;LLC (Nuclear) and PSEG Energy Resources &amp; Trade&nbsp;LLC (ER&amp;T) are regulated by FERC. Through its subsidiaries, Power seeks to balance its generating capacity, fuel requirements and supply obligations through integrated energy marketing and trading, enhance its ability to produce low-cost energy through efficient nuclear operations and pursue modest growth based on market conditions. Changes in the operation of Power&#39;s generating facilities, fuel and capacity prices, expected contract prices, capacity factors or other assumptions
could materially affect its ability to meet earnings targets and/or liquidity requirements. In addition to the electric generation business described above, Power&#39;s revenues include gas supply sales under the BGSS contract with&nbsp;PSE&amp;G.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As a merchant generator, Power&#39;s profit is derived from selling under contract or on the spot market a range of diverse products such as energy, capacity, emissions credits, congestion credits and a series of energy-related products that the system operator uses to optimize the operation of the energy grid, known as ancillary services. Accordingly, the prices of commodities, such as electricity, gas, coal and emissions, as well as the availability of Power&#39;s diverse fleet of generation units to produce these products, can have a material effect on Power&#39;s profitability.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Power seeks to mitigate volatility in its results by contracting in advance for a significant portion of its anticipated electric output and fuel needs. Power believes this contracting strategy increases stability of earnings and cash flow. By keeping some portion of its output uncontracted, Power is able to retain some ability to take advantage of market changes as well as provide some protection in the event of unexpected generation outages.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In a changing market environment, this hedging strategy may cause Power&#39;s realized prices to be materially different than current market prices. At the present time, a significant portion of Power&#39;s existing contractual obligations, entered into during lower-priced periods, resulted in lower margins than would have been the case if no or little hedging activity had been conducted. Alternatively, in a falling price environment, this hedging strategy will tend to create margins in excess of those implied by the then current market.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>For Power&#39;s BGSS contracts, commodity costs are passed on to residential customers. Any differences from the BGSS contract prices are deferred by&nbsp;PSE&amp;G for future recovery. For commercial and industrial (C&amp;I) customers, a tariff structure is applied that is adjusted monthly based on the current New York Mercantile Exchange (NYMEX) prices. During the first half of 2006, market prices for natural gas declined from the historically high price levels experienced in the second half of 2005</font></p>
<p align=center>60</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>while the cost of gas in inventory was relatively stable, which reduced Power&#39;s margins as compared to 2005.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>For the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2006, Power had Net Income of $189 million. Power has raised its earnings guidance from a range of $475 million to $525 million to a range of $500 million to $550&nbsp;million for 2006, reflecting improved results and anticipated continued strong operating performance of its nuclear and fossil stations and attractive contracting opportunities in current energy markets. The guidance range does not include Merger-related costs.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>A key factor in Power&#39;s ability to achieve its objectives is its capability to operate its nuclear and fossil stations at sufficient capacity factors to limit the need to purchase higher-priced electricity to satisfy its obligations. Power&#39;s ability to benefit from any future increases in market prices will depend, to a large extent, on efficient power plant operations, especially for its low-cost nuclear and coal-fired facilities. In addition, since forward prices are constantly changing, there is no assurance that Power will be able to contract its output at attractive prices. While these increases may have a potentially significant beneficial impact on margins, they could also raise any replacement power costs that Power may incur in the event of unanticipated outages, and could also further increase liquidity
requirements as a result of contract obligations. For additional information on liquidity requirements, see Liquidity and Capital Resources.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Energy Holdings&#39; operations are principally conducted through its subsidiaries: Global, which has invested in international, rate-regulated distribution companies and domestic and international merchant generation companies, and Resources, which primarily invests in energy-related leveraged leases.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In the first
  half of 2006, Energy Holdings successfully closed on two major transactions
  as part of its strategy to opportunistically monetize assets that no longer
  have a strategic fit. In May 2006, Global completed the sale of its ownership
  interests in two generating facilities in Poland for $476 million, recording
  an after-tax gain of $228 million, which is included in Income from Discontinued
  Operations. In June 2006, Global completed the sale of its&nbsp;32% interest
  in RGE for $185 million, resulting in an after-tax loss of $177 million. Together,
  Global received gross sales proceeds of $654 million, or approximately $612
  million after taxes, and recorded a net after-tax gain of approximately $51
  million. Energy Holdings is evaluating the use of the proceeds, including potential
  debt redemption and loans and/or dividends to PSEG. As part of this evaluation,
  Energy Holdings and PSEG will review the liquidity needs of their respective
  businesses in balance with maintaining Energy Holdings&#39; credit metrics.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In May 2006, Global also entered into an agreement to sell its&nbsp;46% ownership interest in Dhofar Power Company&nbsp;S.A.O.C. (Dhofar Power), a generation facility and distribution system in Oman, for proceeds of approximately $33 million and an immaterial after-tax gain. The sale of Dhofar Power, which is contingent upon attaining consents from Dhofar Power&#39;s lenders and no objections from the government in Oman, is expected to be completed later in 2006. In May 2006, Global also converted its loans to Prisma 2000&nbsp;S.p.A. (Prisma) to equity, thereby increasing its ownership interest from&nbsp;50% to&nbsp;85% and obtaining operating control of the project. Prisma is a joint venture that operates several biomass generation plants in Italy. See Note&nbsp;3. Discontinued Operations, Dispositions and Acquisitions
of the Notes for further discussion.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>For the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2006, Energy Holdings had Net Income of $150 million, which includes the net gain of $51 million related to the asset sales, discussed above. Energy Holdings&#39; earnings guidance for 2006, which excludes the $51 million net gain, has been increased from a range of $155 million to $175 million to a range of $185 million to $205 million. The increase was largely driven by the strong Texas market where Global operates two gas-fired, combined cycle plants totaling&nbsp;2,000&nbsp;MW through its investment in Texas Independent Energy (TIE). Spark margins, which increased substantially last year compared to previous years, have continued to remain strong and the plants&#39; high availability factors have enabled&nbsp;TIE to benefit from these high margins. Stable earnings</font></p>
<p align=center>61</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>from Global&#39;s South American distribution companies also continue to be a sustainable platform for Energy Holdings&#39; earnings.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Global</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Although Global continues to produce significant earnings and operating cash flow, the returns on several of the investments in its international portfolio have not been commensurate with the level of risk associated with international investments in developing energy markets. As a result, since 2003, Energy Holdings has refocused its strategy from one of growth to one that places emphasis on increasing the efficiency and returns of its existing assets.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Global&#39;s success will depend, in part, upon its ability to mitigate risks of its international strategy. The economic and political conditions in certain countries where Global has investments present risks that may be different or more significant than those found in the&nbsp;U.S., including: renegotiation or nullification of existing contracts, changes in law or tax policy, interruption of business, nationalization, expropriation, war and other factors. Operations in foreign countries also present risks associated with currency exchange and convertibility, inflation and repatriation of earnings. In some countries in which Global has interests, economic and monetary conditions and other factors could affect its ability to convert its cash distributions to&nbsp;U.S. Dollars or other freely-convertible currencies. Furthermore,
the central bank of any such country may have the authority to suspend, restrict or otherwise impose conditions on foreign exchange transactions or to limit distributions to foreign investors.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Resources</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Resources has primarily invested in energy-related leveraged leases. Resources is focused on maintaining its current investment portfolio and does not expect to make any new investments. Resources&#39; ability to realize tax benefits associated with its leveraged lease investments is dependent upon taxable income generated by its affiliates. Resources&#39; earnings and cash flows are expected to decrease in the future as the investment portfolio matures. Resources faces risks related to potential changes in the current accounting and tax treatment of certain investments in leveraged leases. Resources also faces risks with regard to the creditworthiness of its counterparties, specifically certain lessees that collectively comprise a substantial portion of Resources&#39; investment portfolio.</font></p>
<p align=center>62</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>

<div align=left>
<p><font color=#000000><hr color=#000000 noshade align=left width=48 size=0></font></p>
</div>
<table width=100% cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 border=0><tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>(A)</font></td>
<td align=left valign=top nowrap>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>Other activities include non-segment amounts of Energy Holdings and its subsidiaries and intercompany eliminations. Specific amounts include interest on certain financing transactions and certain other administrative and general expenses at Energy Holdings.</font></td></tr>
<tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>(B)</font></td>
<td align=left valign=top nowrap>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>Other activities include non-segment amounts of PSEG (as parent company) and intercompany eliminations. Specific amounts include preferred securities dividends/preference unit distributions for&nbsp;PSE&amp;G in 2006 and 2005 and Energy Holdings in 2005, interest on certain financing transactions, Merger expenses and certain other administrative and general expenses at PSEG (as parent company).</font></td></tr>
<tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>(C)</font></td>
<td align=left valign=top nowrap>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>The Gain on Disposal of Skawina and Elcho is included in 2006 and their Discontinued Operations are included in 2005 and 2006. The Loss on Disposal and Discontinued Operations of Waterford, an electric generation facility in Waterford, Ohio that was sold in September 2005, are included in 2005. See Note&nbsp;3. Discontinued Operations, Dispositions and Acquisitions of the Notes.</font></td></tr>
</table>
<p align=center>63</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<table width=100% cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 border=0><tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>(D)</font></td>
<td align=left valign=top nowrap>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>Earnings Per Share of any segment does not represent a direct legal interest in the assets and liabilities allocated to any one segment but rather represents a direct interest in PSEG&#39;s assets and liabilities as a whole.</font></td></tr>
</table>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $105 million or $0.43 per share decrease in Income from Continuing Operations for the quarter was due to decreases of $117 million and $15 million at Energy Holdings and&nbsp;PSE&amp;G, respectively, partially offset by an increase of $21 million at Power and an improvement of $6 million at PSEG (as parent company), primarily due to decreased merger costs and lower Interest Expense. The decrease at Energy Holdings was primarily due to the $177 million after-tax loss on the sale of&nbsp;RGE in June 2006, which was partially offset by improved operations in Texas and the absence of a $15 million after-tax write-off of Resources&#39; investment in an aircraft lease to United Airlines in June 2005. The decrease at&nbsp;PSE&amp;G was mainly due to the full amortization of the excess depreciation reserve as of December&nbsp;31,
2005. Also decreasing&nbsp;PSE&amp;G&#39;s earnings were reduced demand due to higher pricing and weather. The increase at Power was due principally to higher realized prices from re-contracting its generation portfolio and spot market sales combined with improved nuclear performance. Power&#39;s increases were partially offset by increased costs due to the commencement of commercial operations at Linden and the Bethlehem Energy Center (BEC) in May 2006 and July 2005, respectively, and higher Operation and Maintenance costs.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $186 million or $0.79 per share decrease in Income from Continuing Operations for the six months was due to decreases of $156 million and $55 million at Energy Holdings and&nbsp;PSE&amp;G, respectively, partially offset by an increase of $18 million at Power and an improvement of $7 million at PSEG (as parent company). These changes were primarily attributable to the same reasons discussed above for the quarter. Also contributing to the decrease at Energy Holdings for the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005 was the absence of $37 million of income received in the first quarter of 2005 from withdrawal from the Eagle Point Cogeneration Partnership (EPCP). In addition to the increased costs related to Linden and&nbsp;BEC and higher Operations and Maintenance costs, discussed above,
Power&#39;s increased earnings for the six months were partially offset by reduced margins on BGSS, primarily in the first quarter of 2006 as compared to 2005, as market prices for natural gas declined from the historically high price levels experienced in the second half of 2005 while the cost of gas in inventory was relatively stable.</font></p>

<td align=left valign=bottom><p style='margin-left:1em;text-indent:-1em;'><font color=#000000><small>Operating Revenues</small></font></p></td>
<td align=right valign=bottom nowrap>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</td>
<td align=right valign=bottom nowrap><font color=#000000><small>$</small></font></td>
<td align=right valign=bottom><font color=#000000><small>2,606</small></font></td>

<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG&#39;s results of operations are primarily comprised of the results of operations of its operating subsidiaries, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings, excluding changes related to intercompany transactions, which are eliminated in consolidation and certain financing costs at the parent company. For additional information on intercompany transactions, see Note&nbsp;13. Related-Party Transactions of the Notes. For a discussion of the causes for the variances at PSEG in the table above, see the discussions for&nbsp;PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings that follow.</font></p>

<td align=right valign=bottom><font color=#000000><small>(91</small></font></td>
<td align=left valign=bottom nowrap><font color=#000000><small>)</small></font></td>
<td align=right valign=bottom nowrap>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</td>
<td align=right valign=bottom nowrap><font color=#000000><small>$</small></font></td>
<td align=right valign=bottom><font color=#000000><small>(117</small></font></td>
<td align=left valign=bottom nowrap><font color=#000000><small>)</small></font></td>
<td align=right valign=bottom nowrap>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</td>
<td align=right valign=bottom nowrap><font color=#000000><small>$</small></font></td>
<td align=right valign=bottom><font color=#000000><small>(26</small></font></td>
<td align=left valign=bottom nowrap><font color=#000000><small>)</small></font></td>
<td align=right valign=bottom nowrap>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=right valign=bottom><font color=#000000><small>(22</small></font></td>
<td align=left valign=bottom nowrap><font color=#000000><small>)</small></font><font color=#000000><small></small></font></td></tr>
<tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=left valign=bottom><p style='margin-left:1em;text-indent:-1em;'><font color=#000000><small></small></font></p></td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>

</table>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Operating Revenues</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G has three sources of revenue: commodity revenues from the sales of energy to customers and in the&nbsp;PJM spot market; delivery revenues from the transmission and distribution of energy through its system; and other operating revenues from the provision of various services. The $93 million increase for the quarter ended June&nbsp;30, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, was due to an increase of $90 million in commodity revenues, described below, and $3 million in delivery revenues. The $259&nbsp;million increase for the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, was due to increases of $268 million in commodity revenues, described below, and $1 million in other operating revenues, primarily related to appliance service contracts, partially offset by a $10 million decrease
in delivery revenues.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Commodity</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G makes no margin on commodity sales as the costs are passed through to customers. The difference between gas costs and the amount provided by customers in revenues is deferred and collected from or returned to customers in future periods. Total commodity volumes and revenues are subject to market forces. Gas commodity prices fluctuate monthly for&nbsp;C&amp;I customers and annually through the BGSS tariff for residential customers. In addition, for residential gas customers, PSE&amp;G has the ability to adjust rates upward two additional times and downward at any time, if warranted, between annual BGSS proceedings. Electric commodity prices are set at the annual&nbsp;BGS auctions.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $90 million increase in commodity revenues for the quarter ended June&nbsp;30, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, was due to increases of $81 million in electric commodity revenues, primarily due to $67 million in higher&nbsp;BGS and Non-Utility Generation (NUG) prices and $14 million in higher&nbsp;BGS volumes due to sales growth and higher&nbsp;NUG volumes due to operations. Also contributing to the increase was $9 million in gas commodity revenues, primarily due to $55 million in higher BGSS prices offset by $34 million in lower volumes due to weather and a decrease of $12 million due to the expiration of the Third Party Shopping Incentive in July 2005. There was a corresponding $12 million increase in delivery revenues.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $268 million increase in commodity revenues for the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, was due to increases of $136 million in gas commodity revenues, primarily due to $343 million in higher BGSS prices offset by $149 million in lower volumes due to weather and a decrease of $58 million due to the expiration of the Third Party Shopping Incentive in July 2005. There was a corresponding $58 million increase in delivery revenues. Also contributing to the increase was $132 million in electric commodity revenues, primarily due to $111 million in higher&nbsp;BGS and&nbsp;NUG prices and $21 million in higher&nbsp;BGS volumes due to customer shopping and higher&nbsp;NUG volumes due to operations.</font></p>
<p align=center>65</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Delivery</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $3 million increase in delivery revenues for the quarter ended June&nbsp;30, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, was due to a $2 million increase in gas revenues and a $1 million increase in electric revenues. The $2 million increase in gas delivery revenues was due primarily to $13 million in increased prices, $12 million of which was due to the expiration of the Third Party Shopping Incentive in July 2005, described above in commodity revenues. This increase was offset by $9 million in lower volumes due to weather and $2 million due to impacts of price elasticity. The $1 million increase in electric revenues was due to $4 million in increased volumes due to weather offset by decreased prices of $2 million due to lower demand revenues and $1 million due to lower securitization tariff rates.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $10 million decrease in delivery revenues for the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, was due to a $9 million decrease in electric revenues and a $1 million decrease in gas revenues. The $9 million decrease in electric revenues was due to decreased prices of $4&nbsp;million due to lower demand revenues and $2 million due to lower securitization tariff rates and $3&nbsp;million in lower volumes due to weather. The $1 million decrease in gas delivery revenues was due primarily to $56 million in lower volumes due to weather and $8 million due to impacts of price elasticity. This was offset by $63 million in increased prices, primarily due to the expiration of the Third Party Shopping Incentive in July 2005, described above in commodity revenues.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Operating Expenses</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Energy Costs</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $92 million increase for the quarter ended June&nbsp;30, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, was comprised of increases of $66 million in electric costs and $26 million in gas costs. The electric increase was due to $47 million in higher prices for&nbsp;BGS and&nbsp;NUG purchases and $19 million in higher&nbsp;BGS and&nbsp;NUG volumes. The increase in gas costs was caused by a $61 million or&nbsp;10% increase in gas prices offset by a $35 million decrease in sales volumes due primarily to weather.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $299 million increase for the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, was comprised of increases of $194 million in gas costs and $105 million in electric costs. The increase in gas costs was caused by a $352 million or&nbsp;28% increase in gas prices offset by an $8 million decrease due to the expiration of the Gas Cost Underrecovery Adjustment (GCUA) clause in January 2005, and a $150 million decrease in sales volumes due primarily to weather. The electric increase was due to $73 million in higher prices for&nbsp;BGS and&nbsp;NUG purchases and $32 million in higher&nbsp;NUG volumes.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Operation and Maintenance</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $8 million increase for the quarter ended June&nbsp;30, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, was due primarily to $4 million in increased labor and fringe benefits due to increased wages and Other Postretirement Benefits (OPEB) costs and $2 million in increased bad debt expense.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $14 million increase for the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, was due primarily to $8 million in increased labor and fringe benefits due to increased wages and OPEB costs and $6 million in increased bad debt expense.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Depreciation and Amortization</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $22 million increase for the quarter ended June&nbsp;30, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, was due primarily to a $23 million increase in the amortization of regulatory assets offset by a $1&nbsp;million decrease in software amortization.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $39 million increase for the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, was due primarily to a $43 million increase in the amortization of regulatory assets. This was offset by a $3 million decrease in software amortization and a $1 million decrease in the amortization of the Remediation Adjustment Clause (RAC).</font></p>
<p align=center>66</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Other Income</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Other Income increased $6 million for the quarter ended June&nbsp;30, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, primarily due to $5 million in an income tax gross-up on contributions in aid of construction (CIAC). CIAC is taxable and&nbsp;PSE&amp;G recognizes the gross-up as income when collected. Also contributing to the increase was $1 million in increased income on investments.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Other Income increased $8 million for the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, primarily due to $5 million in an income tax gross-up on CIAC. Also contributing to the increase was $2 million in increased income on investments.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Income Taxes</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Income Taxes decreased $5 million for the quarter and $26 million for the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2006, as compared to the same periods in 2005, primarily due to lower pre-tax income.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></p>

<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Operating Revenues</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $75 million increase for the quarter ended June&nbsp;30, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, was due to increases of $71 million in generation revenues and $11 million in trading revenues, partially offset by a decrease of $7 million in gas supply revenues.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $312 million increase for the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, was due to increases of $222 million in generation revenues, $77 million in gas supply revenues and $13 million in trading revenues.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Generation</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The increase of $71 million and $222 million in generation revenues for the quarter and six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2006, respectively, as compared to the same periods in 2005, was primarily due to higher sales volumes in the various power pools, supported by improved nuclear operations and the commencement of the commercial operations of Linden in May 2006 and&nbsp;BEC in July 2005, and higher prices. The increases were partially offset by a reduction in load being served under the&nbsp;BGS contracts and lower fees for ancillary services.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Gas Supply</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Gas supply revenues decreased $7 million for the quarter ended June&nbsp;30, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, principally due to lower demand under the BGSS contract, largely resulting from customer conservation and milder weather in 2006, substantially offset by higher prices for gas sales.</font></p>
<p align=center>67</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $77 million increase in gas supply revenues for the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, was primarily due to higher gas prices under the BGSS contract and from sales to nonaffiliated commercial end-users for gas and pipeline capacity. Increased prices were partially offset by lower demand in 2006, largely due to customer conservation and a milder winter heating season.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Trading</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $11 million and $13 million increase in trading revenues for the quarter and six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2006, respectively, as compared to the same periods in 2005, was primarily due to higher realized gains related to emissions credits.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Operating Expenses</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Energy Costs</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Energy Costs represent the cost of generation, which includes fuel purchases for generation as well as purchased energy in the market, and gas purchases to meet Power&#39;s obligation under its BGSS contract with&nbsp;PSE&amp;G.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Energy Costs decreased approximately $13 million for the quarter ended June&nbsp;30, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, primarily due to lower generation costs, reflecting decreases of $36 million resulting from a reduction in the volume of purchases from the various power pools due to higher generation and lower pool prices and $33 million due to favorable pricing of fuel-related asset-backed transactions in 2006. These decreases were substantially offset by higher fossil fuel expenses, largely due to a higher volume of gas purchased to operate Linden and&nbsp;BEC.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $204 million increase for the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, was primarily due to $130 million from higher prices on a reduced volume of gas purchased to satisfy Power&#39;s BGSS obligations and $74 million from a higher volume of fossil fuel purchases to support generation by Linden and&nbsp;BEC.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Operation and Maintenance</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Operation and Maintenance expense increased $29 million and $37 million for the quarter and six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2006, respectively, as compared to the same periods in 2005, due to higher maintenance costs at certain of the fossil plants, the addition of costs in 2006 related to&nbsp;BEC and Linden and the absence of a $6 million real estate tax refund recognized in 2005. These increases were partially offset by reductions in labor costs in 2006 due to a reduction in personnel at the nuclear generating facilities and other Power locations and the absence of a $10 million restructuring charge incurred in 2005 related to Nuclear&#39;s workforce realignment plan.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Depreciation and Amortization</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $8 million and $13 million increase for the quarter and six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2006, respectively, as compared to the same periods in 2005, was primarily due to Linden and&nbsp;BEC being placed into service.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Other Income</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Other Income increased $4 million and $14 million for the quarter and six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2006, respectively, as compared to the same periods in 2005, primarily due to increased realized gains and income related to the&nbsp;NDT Funds and higher interest on margin call deposits.</font></p>
<p align=center>68</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Other Deductions</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Other Deductions increased $2 million and $13 million for the quarter and six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2006, respectively, as compared to the same periods in 2005, primarily due to increased realized losses and miscellaneous expenses related to the&nbsp;NDT Funds.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Interest Expense</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Interest Expense increased $18 million and $30 million for the quarter and six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2006, respectively, as compared to the same periods in 2005, due primarily to lower capitalized interest costs in 2006 related to commencement of operations of the&nbsp;BEC facility in July 2005 and the Linden facility in May 2006.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Income Taxes</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Income Taxes increased $14 million for the quarter and $11 million for the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2006, as compared to the same periods in 2005, primarily due to higher pre-tax income.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Loss from Discontinued Operations, including Loss on Disposal, net of tax</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On May&nbsp;27, 2005, Power reached an agreement to sell its Waterford generation facility for approximately $220 million and recognized a loss on disposal of approximately $177 million for the initial write-down of its carrying amount of Waterford to its fair value less cost to sell. The loss from the discontinued operating results of Waterford was $6 million and $13 million for the quarter and six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2005, respectively. See Note&nbsp;3. Discontinued Operations, Dispositions and Acquisitions of the Notes for additional information.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Energy Holdings</font></b></p>

<td align=right valign=bottom nowrap>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=right valign=bottom><font color=#000000><small>N/A</small></font></td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td></tr>
<tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=left valign=bottom><p style='margin-left:1em;text-indent:-1em;'><font color=#000000><small></small></font></p></td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>

<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>

<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td></tr>
</table>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The variances in Operating Revenues, Energy Costs, Operation and Maintenance, Depreciation and Amortization and Income from Equity Method Investments were partially attributed to Global&#39;s sale of a&nbsp;35% interest in Dhofar Power Company&nbsp;S.A.O.C. (Dhofar Power) through a public offering on the Omani Stock Exchange in April 2005, reducing its ownership interest to&nbsp;46% and thus accounting for the investment under the equity method of accounting following the sale. The variances are also related to Global&#39;s increased ownership interest in Prisma from&nbsp;50% to&nbsp;85%, thus consolidating the entity effective May 2006. See Note&nbsp;3. Discontinued Operations, Dispositions and Acquisitions of the Notes.</font></p>
<p align=center>69</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Operating Revenues</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $97 million increase for the quarter ended June&nbsp;30, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, was due to higher revenues at Global of $80 million, which was the net result of a $57 million increase at&nbsp;TIE due to an increase in the average price per megawatt hour, a $25 million increase at Sociedad Austral de Electricidad&nbsp;S.A. (SAESA) in Chile due to increased tariff prices and volume, a $2 million increase at Electroandes&nbsp;S.A. (Electroandes) due to higher energy sales and a $7 million increase due to the consolidation of Prisma, partially offset by the absence of a $3 million pre-tax gain recognized in 2005 related to sale of Global&#39;s&nbsp;35% interest in Dhofar Power and a $5 million decrease related to the deconsolidation of Dhofar Power. Also contributing to the increase were higher revenues
at Resources of $17 million primarily due to the absence of a $22 million pre-tax write-off of its leveraged lease investment with United Airlines recorded in 2005.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $96 million increase for the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, was due to higher revenues at Global of $93 million, which was the net result of a $102 million increase at&nbsp;TIE due to an increase in the average price per megawatt hour, a $40 million increase at SAESA due to increased tariffs and volume, a $4 million increase at Electroandes due to higher energy sales and a $7 million increase due to the consolidation of Prisma, partially offset by decreased revenues due to the absence of $37 million of income received in 2005 from withdrawal from EPCP, the absence of a $3 million pre-tax gain recognized in 2005 related to sale of Global&#39;s&nbsp;35% interest in Dhofar Power and a $20 million decrease related to the deconsolidation of Dhofar Power, respectively. Also contributing
to the increase were higher revenues at Resources of $3 million primarily due to the absence of a $22 million pre-tax write-off of its leveraged lease investment with United Airlines recorded in 2005 partially offset by the reduction in leveraged lease income.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Operating Expenses</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Energy Costs</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $32 million increase for the quarter ended June&nbsp;30, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, was primarily due to a $14 million increase at&nbsp;TIE resulting from an increase in gas prices, a $19 million increase related to SAESA due to increased volume and increases in energy costs due to higher spot prices and a $3 million increase due to the consolidation of Prisma, partially offset by a $2 million decrease related to the deconsolidation of Dhofar Power.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $88 million increase for the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, was primarily due to a $61 million increase at&nbsp;TIE resulting from an increase in gas prices, a $29 million increase related to SAESA due to increased volume and increases in energy costs due to higher spot prices and a $3 million increase due to the consolidation of Prisma, partially offset by a $5 million decrease related to the deconsolidation of Dhofar Power.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Operation and Maintenance</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $9 million decrease for the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, was primarily due to a $16 million decrease at&nbsp;TIE resulting from a scheduled hot gas path inspection outage that occurred in the first quarter of 2005 and a $3 million decrease related to the deconsolidation of Dhofar Power, offset by an $8 million increase related to SAESA due to repairs of a gas turbine and other costs and a $1 million increase due to the consolidation of Prisma.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Write-down of Project Investments</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $263 million write-down of project investments relates to Global&#39;s sale of its&nbsp;32% indirect ownership interest in&nbsp;RGE to its partner. See Note&nbsp;3. Discontinued Operations, Dispositions and Acquisitions of the Notes.</font></p>
<p align=center>70</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Income from Equity Method Investments</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $3 million increase for the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, was primarily due to stronger results from Global&#39;s investments in Hawaii (Kalaeloa) and California (GWF).</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Other Income</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $10 million increase for the quarter ended June&nbsp;30, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, was primarily due to an increase in interest and dividend income primarily related to an intercompany loan to PSEG.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $10 million increase for the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, was primarily due to foreign exchange gains.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Other Deductions</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $3 million decrease for the quarter ended June&nbsp;30, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, was primarily due to foreign currency losses.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Interest Expense</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $3 million and $11 million decrease for the quarter and six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2006, respectively, as compared to the same periods in 2005, was primarily due to a decrease in Energy Holdings&#39; debt outstanding.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Income Taxes</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $64 million and $66 million net increase in income tax benefits for the quarter and six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2006, respectively, as compared to the same periods in 2005, was primarily due to the tax benefit recognized in 2006 related to the write-down of project investments due to Global&#39;s sale of its&nbsp;32% indirect ownership interest in&nbsp;RGE.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Income from Discontinued Operations, including Gain on Disposal, net of tax</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In May 2006, Global completed the sale of its interest in two coal-fired plants in Poland, Elcho and Skawina. The sale resulted in an after-tax gain of $228 million. (Loss) Income from Discontinued Operations related to Elcho and Skawina for the quarters ended June&nbsp;30, 2006 and 2005 was $(5) million and $10 million, respectively. (Loss) Income from Discontinued Operations related to Elcho and Skawina for the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2006 and 2005 was $(1) million and $22 million, respectively. See Note&nbsp;3. Discontinued Operations, Dispositions and Acquisitions of the Notes for additional information.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000><a name='liquidity'>LIQUIDITY&nbsp;AND CAPITAL RESOURCES</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The following discussion of liquidity and capital resources is on a consolidated basis for PSEG, noting the uses and contributions of PSEG&#39;s three direct operating subsidiaries, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Operating Cash Flows</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>For the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2006, PSEG&#39;s operating cash flow increased approximately $242 million from $563 million to $805 million, as compared to the same period in 2005, primarily due to net increases from its subsidiaries as discussed below.</font></p>
<p align=center>71</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G&#39;s operating cash flow increased approximately $73 million from $56 million to $129 million for the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, primarily due to less funding for employee benefit plans and higher over recovery of gas costs.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Power&#39;s operating cash flow increased approximately $305 million from $416 million to $721 million for the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, due to decreased margin requirements and a decrease in fuel inventory due to decreased commodity prices and a reduction in natural gas inventory following the winter heating season.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Energy Holdings&#39; operating cash flow decreased approximately $134 million from $152 million to $18 million for the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, due primarily to the timing of tax payments and benefits associated with the sales of Elcho, Skawina and&nbsp;RGE and other matters. The proceeds from these sales are included in Investing Activities on the Statements of Cash Flows.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Common Stock Dividends</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Dividend payments on common stock for the quarters ended June&nbsp;30, 2006 and 2005 were $0.57 and $0.56 per share, respectively, and totaled approximately $143 million and $133 million, respectively. Dividend payments on common stock for the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2006 and 2005 were $1.14 and $1.12 per share, respectively, and totaled approximately $286 million and $267 million, respectively. Future dividends declared will be dependent upon PSEG&#39;s future earnings, cash flows, financial requirements, alternative investment opportunities and other factors. On July&nbsp;18, 2006, PSEG&#39;s Board of Directors approved a common stock dividend of $0.57 per share for the third quarter of 2006, reflecting an indicated annual dividend rate of $2.28 per share.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Short-Term Liquidity</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As of June&nbsp;30, 2006, PSEG and its subsidiaries had a total of approximately $3.7 billion of committed credit facilities with approximately $2.9 billion of available liquidity under these facilities. In addition, PSEG and&nbsp;PSE&amp;G have access to certain uncommitted credit facilities. Each of the facilities is restricted to availability and use to the specific companies as listed below.</font></p>
