<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG and&nbsp;PSE&amp;G</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG and&nbsp;PSE&amp;G believe sufficient liquidity exists to fund their short-term cash needs.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As of June&nbsp;30, 2006, Power had borrowed $145 million from PSEG in the form of an intercompany loan.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>During the second quarter of 2006, Power&#39;s required margin postings decreased for sales contracts entered into in the normal course of business as commodity prices declined. The required margin postings will fluctuate based on volatility in commodity prices. Should commodity prices rise, additional margin calls may be necessary relative to existing power sales contracts. As Power&#39;s contract obligations are fulfilled, liquidity requirements are reduced. Power believes that it has sufficient liquidity to fund its short-term cash needs.</font></p>
<p align=center>73</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In addition, ER&amp;T maintains agreements that require Power, as its guarantor under performance guarantees, to satisfy certain creditworthiness standards. In the event of a deterioration of Power&#39;s credit rating to below investment grade, which represents at least a two level downgrade from its current ratings, many of these agreements allow the counterparty to demand that&nbsp;ER&amp;T provide performance assurance, generally in the form of a letter of credit or cash. Providing this support would increase Power&#39;s costs of doing business and could restrict the ability of&nbsp;ER&amp;T to manage and optimize Power&#39;s asset portfolio. Power believes it has sufficient liquidity to meet any required posting of collateral resulting from a credit rating downgrade. See Note&nbsp;5. Commitments and Contingent Liabilities
of the Notes for further information.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Energy Holdings
  and its subsidiaries had $101 million in cash, including $10 million invested
  offshore as of June&nbsp;30, 2006. In addition, as of June&nbsp;30, 2006, Energy
  Holdings had loaned $708 million of excess cash to PSEG, including a $450 million
  term loan expiring September&nbsp;30, 2006. For further information see Note&nbsp;13.
  Related-Party Transactions of the Notes. Energy Holdings is evaluating the use
  of the proceeds from these sales, including potential debt redemption and loans
  and/or dividends to PSEG. As part of this evaluation, Energy Holdings and PSEG
  will review the liquidity needs of their respective businesses in balance with
  maintaining Energy Holdings&#39; credit metrics.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>External Financings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>During the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2006, PSEG issued approximately&nbsp;523,000 shares of its common stock under its Dividend Reinvestment Program and Employee Stock Purchase Program for approximately $34 million.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In February 2006, PSEG redeemed $154 million of its Subordinated Debentures underlying $150 million of Enterprise Capital Trust&nbsp;II, Floating Rate Capital Securities and its common equity investment in the trust.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On June&nbsp;23, 2006, PSE&amp;G repaid at maturity $174 million of its Floating Rate Series&nbsp;A First and Refunding Mortgage Bonds.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On March&nbsp;1, 2006, PSE&amp;G repaid at maturity $148 million of its&nbsp;6.75% Series&nbsp;UU First and Refunding Mortgage Bonds.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In June 2006 and March 2006, PSE&amp;G Transition Funding&nbsp;LLC (Transition Funding) repaid approximately $35 million and $36 million, respectively, of its transition bonds.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In June 2006, PSE&amp;G Transition Funding&nbsp;II LLC (Transition Funding&nbsp;II) repaid approximately $3 million of its transition bonds.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In April 2006, Power repaid at maturity $500 million of its&nbsp;6.875% Senior Notes.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In January 2006, Energy Holdings redeemed all $309 million of its&nbsp;7.75% Senior Notes due in 2007.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On February&nbsp;17, 2006, the maturity of the Odessa&ndash;Ector Power Partners, L.P. (Odessa) debt was extended to December&nbsp;31, 2009. Interest on the debt is based on a spread (currently&nbsp;2.25%) above LIBOR. On September&nbsp;29, 2006, an interest rate swap will take effect which will convert the floating LIBOR interest rate on approximately&nbsp;80% of Odessa&#39;s debt to a fixed rate of&nbsp;5.4275% through December&nbsp;31, 2009.</font></p>
<p align=center>74</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Debt Covenants</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG&#39;s, PSE&amp;G&#39;s, Power&#39;s and Energy Holdings&#39; respective credit agreements generally contain customary provisions under which the lenders can refuse to advance loans in the event of a material adverse change in the borrower&#39;s business or financial condition.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As explained in more detail below, these credit agreements may also contain maximum debt to equity ratios, minimum cash flow tests and other restrictive covenants and conditions to borrowing. Compliance with applicable financial covenants will depend upon the respective future financial position, level of earnings and cash flows of PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings, as to which no assurances can be given. The ratios presented below are for the benefit of the investors of the related securities to which the covenants apply. They are not intended as a financial performance or liquidity measure.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Financial covenants contained in PSEG&#39;s credit facilities include a ratio of debt (excluding non-recourse project financings, securitization debt and debt underlying preferred securities and including commercial paper and loans, certain letters of credit and similar instruments) to total capitalization (including preferred securities outstanding) covenant. This covenant requires that at the end of any quarterly financial period, such ratio not be more than&nbsp;70.0%. As of June&nbsp;30, 2006, PSEG&#39;s ratio of debt to capitalization (as defined above) was&nbsp;55.0%.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Financial covenants contained in&nbsp;PSE&amp;G&#39;s credit facilities include a ratio of long-term debt (excluding securitization debt, long-term debt maturing within one year and short-term debt) to total capitalization covenant. This covenant requires that at the end of any quarterly financial period, such ratio will not be more than&nbsp;65.0%. As of June&nbsp;30, 2006, PSE&amp;G&#39;s ratio of long-term debt to total capitalization (as defined above) was&nbsp;46.0%.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In addition, under its First and Refunding Mortgage (Mortgage), PSE&amp;G may issue new First and Refunding Mortgage Bonds against previous additions and improvements, provided that its ratio of earnings to fixed charges calculated in accordance with its Mortgage is at least&nbsp;2 to&nbsp;1, and/or against retired Mortgage Bonds. As of June&nbsp;30, 2006, PSE&amp;G&#39;s Mortgage coverage ratio was&nbsp;4.8 to&nbsp;1 and the Mortgage would permit up to approximately $1.9 billion aggregate principal amount of new Mortgage Bonds to be issued against previous additions and improvements.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG and Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Financial covenants contained in the PSEG/Power joint and several credit facility include a ratio of debt to total capitalization for each specific borrower. This facility has a&nbsp;70.0% debt to total capitalization covenant for PSEG (calculated as set forth above) and a&nbsp;65.0% debt to total capitalization covenant for Power. The Power ratio is the same debt to total capitalization calculation as set forth above for PSEG except common equity is adjusted for the $986 million Basis Adjustment (see Condensed Consolidated Balance Sheets). This covenant requires that at the end of any quarterly financial period, such ratio will not exceed&nbsp;65.0%. As of June&nbsp;30, 2006, Power&#39;s ratio of debt to total capitalization (as defined above) was&nbsp;43.8%.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Energy Holdings&#39; revolving credit agreement has a covenant requiring the ratio of Earnings Before Interest, Taxes, Depreciation and Amortization (EBITDA) to fixed charges to be greater than or equal to&nbsp;1.75. As of June&nbsp;30, 2006, Energy Holdings&#39; coverage of this covenant was&nbsp;3.44. Additionally, Energy Holdings must maintain a ratio of net debt (recourse debt offset by funds loaned to PSEG) to EBITDA of less than&nbsp;5.25. As of June&nbsp;30, 2006, Energy Holdings&#39; ratio under this covenant was&nbsp;1.62. Energy Holdings is a co-borrower under this facility with Global and Resources, which are joint and several obligors. The terms of the agreement include a pledge of Energy Holdings&#39; membership interest in Global, restrictions on the use of proceeds related to material sales of assets and
the satisfaction of</font></p>
<p align=center>75</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>certain financial covenants. Net cash proceeds from asset sales in excess of&nbsp;5% of total assets of Energy Holdings during any 12-month period must be used to repay any outstanding amounts under the credit agreement. Net cash proceeds from asset sales during any 12-month period in excess of&nbsp;10% of total assets must be retained by Energy Holdings or used to repay the debt of Energy Holdings, Global or Resources.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Credit Ratings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The current ratings of securities of PSEG and its subsidiaries are shown below and reflect the respective views of the rating agencies. Any downward revision or withdrawal may adversely affect the market price of PSEG&#39;s, PSE&amp;G&#39;s, Power&#39;s and Energy Holdings&#39; securities and serve to materially increase those companies&#39; cost of capital and limit their access to capital. All ratings have a stable outlook unless otherwise noted. (N) denotes a negative outlook, (P) denotes a positive outlook and (WD) denotes a credit watch developing, indicating that ratings could be raised or lowered. There is no assurance that the ratings will continue for any given period of time or that they will not be revised by the rating agencies, if, in their respective judgments, circumstances so warrant. Each rating given by
an agency should be evaluated independently of the other agencies&#39; ratings. The ratings should not be construed as an indication to buy, hold or sell any security.</font></p>

</table>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Other Comprehensive Income (OCI)</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>For the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2006, PSEG, Power and Energy Holdings had&nbsp;OCI of $370 million, $179 million and $191 million, respectively, due primarily to a reduction in the net unrealized losses on derivatives accounted for as hedges in accordance with SFAS&nbsp;133 at Power and foreign currency translation adjustments at Energy Holdings.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>During the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2006, Power&#39;s Accumulated Other Comprehensive Loss (OCL) decreased from $487 million to $308 million. The primary cause was a decrease of approximately $179 million related to energy and related contracts that qualify for hedge accounting that were entered into by Power in the normal course of business. During the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2006, the decrease in gas and electric prices resulted in a reduction in unrealized losses on many of those contracts, which are recorded in&nbsp;OCL.</font></p>
<p align=center>76</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>During the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2006, Energy Holdings&#39; Accumulated Other Comprehensive (Loss) Income increased from $(110) million to $81 million. The primary cause was due to the realization of losses on Brazilian currency as a result of the sale of&nbsp;RGE.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000><a name='capital'></font><font color=#000000>CAPITAL REQUIREMENTS</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>It is expected that the majority of funding for capital requirements of&nbsp;PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings will come from their respective internally generated funds. The balance will be provided by the issuance of debt at the respective subsidiary or project level and, for&nbsp;PSE&amp;G and Power, equity contributions from PSEG. PSEG does not expect to contribute any additional equity to Energy Holdings. Projected construction and investment expenditures for PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings are consistent with amounts disclosed in the Annual Reports on Form&nbsp;10-K of PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2005, with the exception of the indefinite postponement of the $30 million Electroandes hydro-expansion project at Energy Holdings which was planned for 2006
and 2007. For further information see Note&nbsp;5. Commitments and Contingent Liabilities of the Notes.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>During the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2006, PSE&amp;G made approximately $259 million of capital expenditures, primarily for reliability of transmission and distribution systems. The $259 million excludes approximately $17 million spent on cost of removal.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>During the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2006, Power made approximately $147 million of capital expenditures (excluding $46 million for nuclear fuel), primarily related to various projects at Fossil and Nuclear.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>During the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2006, Energy Holdings incurred approximately $20 million of capital expenditures, primarily related to SAESA.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000><a name='accounting'></font><font color=#000000>ACCOUNTING MATTERS</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>For information related to recent accounting matters, see Note&nbsp;2. Recent Accounting Standards of the Notes.</font></p>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000><a name='qualitative'>ITEM&nbsp;3. QUALITATIVE&nbsp;AND QUANTITATIVE DISCLOSURES<br>
ABOUT MARKET RISK</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The market risk inherent in PSEG&#39;s, PSE&amp;G&#39;s, Power&#39;s and Energy Holdings&#39; market-risk sensitive instruments and positions is the potential loss arising from adverse changes in foreign currency exchange rates, commodity prices, equity security prices and interest rates as discussed in the Notes to Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements (Notes). It is the policy of each entity to use derivatives to manage risk consistent with its respective business plans and prudent practices. PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings have a Risk Management Committee (RMC) comprised of executive officers who utilize an independent risk oversight function to ensure compliance with corporate policies and prudent risk management practices.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Additionally, PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings are exposed to counterparty credit losses in the event of non-performance or non-payment. PSEG has a credit management process, which is used to assess, monitor and mitigate counterparty exposure for PSEG and its subsidiaries. In the</font></p>
<p align=center>77</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>event of non-performance or non-payment by a major counterparty, there may be a material adverse impact on PSEG and its subsidiaries&#39; financial condition, results of operations or net cash flows.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Except as discussed below, there were no material changes from the disclosures in the Annual Reports on Form&nbsp;10-K of PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2005 or Quarterly Reports on Form&nbsp;10-Q for the quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2006.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Commodity Contracts</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The availability and price of energy commodities are subject to fluctuations from factors such as weather, environmental policies, changes in supply and demand, state and federal regulatory policies, market rules and other events. To reduce price risk caused by market fluctuations, Power enters into supply contracts and derivative contracts, including forwards, futures, swaps and options with approved counterparties. These contracts, in conjunction with demand obligations, help reduce risk and optimize the value of owned electric generation capacity.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Normal Operations and Hedging Activities</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Power enters into physical contracts, as well as financial contracts, including forwards, futures, swaps and options designed to reduce risk associated with volatile commodity prices. Commodity price risk is associated with market price movements resulting from market generation demand, changes in fuel costs and various other factors.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Under SFAS&nbsp;No. 133, &ldquo;Accounting for Derivative Instruments and Hedging Activities&rdquo;, as amended (SFAS&nbsp;133), changes in the fair value of qualifying cash flow hedge transactions are recorded in Accumulated Other Comprehensive Loss (OCL), and gains and losses are recognized in earnings when the underlying transaction occurs. Changes in the fair value of derivative contracts that do not meet hedge criteria under SFAS&nbsp;133 and the ineffective portion of hedge contracts are recognized in earnings currently. Additionally, changes in the fair value attributable to fair value hedges are similarly recognized in earnings.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Many non-trading contracts qualify for the normal purchases and normal sales exemption under SFAS&nbsp;133 and are accounted for upon settlement.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Trading</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Power maintains a strategy of entering into trading positions to optimize the value of its portfolio of generation assets, gas supply contracts and its electric and gas supply obligations. Power engages in physical and financial transactions in the electricity wholesale markets and executes an overall risk management strategy to mitigate the effects of adverse movements in the fuel and electricity markets. In addition, Power has non-asset based trading activities, which have significantly decreased over the past year. These contracts also involve financial transactions including swaps, options and futures. These activities are marked to market in accordance with SFAS&nbsp;133 with gains and losses recognized in earnings.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Value-at-Risk (VaR) Models</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Power uses VaR models to assess the market risk of its commodity businesses. The portfolio VaR model for Power includes its owned generation and physical contracts, as well as fixed price sales requirements, load requirements and financial derivative instruments. VaR represents the potential gains or losses, under normal market conditions, for instruments or portfolios due to changes in market factors, for a specified time period and confidence level. Power estimates VaR across its commodity businesses.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Power manages its exposure at the portfolio level. Its portfolio consists of owned generation, load-serving contracts (both gas and electric), fuel supply contracts and energy derivatives designed to manage the risk around generation and load. While Power manages its risk at the portfolio level, it also monitors separately the risk of its trading activities and its hedges. Non-trading mark-to-market (MTM)</font></p>
<p align=center>78</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>VaR consists of&nbsp;MTM derivatives that are economic hedges, some of which qualify for hedge accounting. The&nbsp;MTM derivatives that are not hedges are included in the trading VaR.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The VaR models used by Power are variance/covariance models adjusted for the delta of positions with a&nbsp;95% one-tailed confidence level and a one-day holding period for the&nbsp;MTM trading and non-trading activities and a&nbsp;95% one-tailed confidence level with a one-week holding period for the portfolio VaR. The models assume no new positions throughout the holding periods, whereas Power actively manages its portfolio.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As of each of June&nbsp;30, 2006 and December&nbsp;31, 2005, trading VaR was less than $1&nbsp;million.</font></p>
<table width=100% cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 border=0><tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#ffffff>&nbsp;</td>

<hr color=#000000 noshade size=1></small></font></b></td>

<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Other Supplemental Information Regarding Market Risk</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The following presentation of the activities of Power is included to address the recommended disclosures by the energy industry&#39;s Committee of Chief Risk Officers. For additional information, see Note&nbsp;6. Risk Management of the Notes.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The following table describes the drivers of Power&#39;s energy trading and marketing activities and Operating Revenues included in its Condensed Consolidated Statement of Operations for the quarter and six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2006. Normal operations and hedging activities represent the marketing of electricity available from Power&#39;s owned or contracted generation sold into the wholesale market. As the information in this table highlights, MTM activities represent a small portion of the total Operating Revenues for Power. Activities accounted for under the accrual method, including normal purchases and sales, account for the majority of the revenue. The MTM activities reported here are those relating to changes in fair value due to external movement in prices.</font></p>
<p align=center>79</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">

<div align=left>
<p><font color=#000000><hr color=#000000 noshade align=left width=48 size=0></font></p>
</div>
<table width=100% cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 border=0><tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>(A)</font></td>
<td align=left valign=top nowrap>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>Includes derivative contracts that Power enters into to hedge anticipated exposures related to its owned and contracted generation supply, all asset-backed transactions and hedging activities, but excludes owned and contracted generation assets.</font></td></tr>
</table>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The following table indicates Power&#39;s energy trading assets and liabilities, as well as Power&#39;s hedging activity related to asset-backed transactions and derivative instruments that qualify for hedge accounting under SFAS&nbsp;133, its amendments and related guidance. This table presents amounts segregated by portfolio which are then netted for those counterparties with whom Power has the right to offset and therefore, are not necessarily indicative of amounts presented on the Condensed Consolidated Balance Sheets since balances with many counterparties are subject to offset and are shown net on the Condensed Consolidated Balance Sheets regardless of the portfolio in which they are included.</font></p>
<p align=center>80</p>

<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Wherever possible, fair values for these contracts were obtained from quoted market sources. For contracts where no quoted market exists, modeling techniques were employed using assumptions reflective of current market rates, yield curves and forward prices as applicable to interpolate certain prices. The effect of using such modeling techniques is not material to Power&#39;s financial results.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The following table identifies losses on cash flow hedges that are currently in OCL, a separate component of equity. Power uses forward sale and purchase contracts, swaps and firm transmission rights (FTRs) contracts to hedge forecasted energy sales from its generation stations and its contracted supply obligations. Power also enters into swaps, options and futures transactions to hedge the price of fuel to meet its fuel purchase requirements for generation. PSEG, Power and Energy Holdings are subject to the risk of fluctuating interest rates in the normal course of business. PSEG&#39;s policy is to manage interest rate risk through the use of fixed rate debt, floating rate debt and interest rate derivatives. The table also provides an estimate of the losses that are expected to be reclassified out of&nbsp;OCL and into
earnings over the next 12&nbsp;months.</font></p>
<p align=center>81</p>

<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Credit Risk</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The following table provides information on Power&#39;s credit exposure, net of collateral, as of June&nbsp;30, 2006. Credit exposure is defined as any positive results of netting accounts receivable/accounts payable and the forward value on open positions. It further delineates that exposure by the credit rating of the counterparties and provides guidance on the concentration of credit risk to individual counterparties and an indication of the maturity of a company&#39;s credit risk by credit rating of the counterparties.</font></p>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>Schedule of Credit Risk Exposure on Energy Contracts Net Assets<br>
As of June&nbsp;30, 2006</font></b></p>

</div>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>(A)&nbsp;Counterparty is&nbsp;PSE&amp;G.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The net exposure listed above, in some cases, will not be the difference between the current exposure and the collateral held. A counterparty may have posted more collateral than the outstanding exposure, in which case there would not be exposure.</font></p>
<p align=center>82</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000><a name='controls'>ITEM&nbsp;4. CONTROLS&nbsp;AND PROCEDURES</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Disclosure Controls and Procedures</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings have established and maintain disclosure controls and procedures which are designed to provide reasonable assurance that information required to be disclosed is recorded, processed, summarized and reported within the time periods specified in the&nbsp;SEC&#39;s rules and forms and that material information relating to each company, including their respective consolidated subsidiaries, is accumulated and communicated to the respective company&#39;s management, including the Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer of each company by others within those entities to allow timely decisions regarding required disclosure. PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings have established a disclosure committee which is made up of several key management employees and which reports
directly to the Chief Financial Officer and Chief Executive Officer of each respective company. The committee monitors and evaluates the effectiveness of these disclosure controls and procedures. The Chief Financial Officer and Chief Executive Officer of each company have evaluated the effectiveness of the disclosure controls and procedures as of June&nbsp;30, 2006 and, based on this evaluation, have concluded that the disclosure controls and procedures were effective in providing reasonable assurance during the period covered in these quarterly reports.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Internal Controls</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>During the second quarter of 2006, PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings each made significant enhancements to internal controls. These enhancements included improvements to internal controls, policies and procedures in the area of derivative accounting.</font></p>
<p align=center>83</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>

<p align=center><b><font color=#000000><a name='other'>ITEM&nbsp;5. OTHER INFORMATION</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Certain information reported under the 2005 Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K and the Quarterly Report on Form&nbsp;10-Q for the quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2006 is updated below. Additionally, certain information is provided for new matters that have arisen subsequent to the filing of the 2005 Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K and Quarterly Report on Form&nbsp;10-Q for the quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2006. References are to the related pages on the Form&nbsp;10-K and Form&nbsp;10-Q as printed and distributed.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Federal Regulation</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Public Utility Holding Company Act</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>2005 Form&nbsp;10-K, Page&nbsp;15.</font></b></i><font color=#000000> The Energy Policy Act, which became law on August&nbsp;8, 2005, repealed the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935 (PUHCA) as of February&nbsp;8, 2006 and established PUHCA 2005. FERC has promulgated rules that would waive the accounting and reporting obligations of PUHCA 2005 for PSEG and its subsidiaries. Thus, PSEG, PSE&amp;G, and Power do not expect PUHCA 2005 to materially affect their respective businesses, prospects or properties. For additional information on the impact of PUHCA repeal, see State Regulation.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>FERC</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><u><font color=#000000>Market Power</font></u></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>2005 Form&nbsp;10-K, Page&nbsp;16 and March&nbsp;31, 2006 Form&nbsp;10-Q, Page&nbsp;78. </font></b></i><font color=#000000>On February&nbsp;28, 2006, PSEG Power Connecticut&nbsp;LLC (Power Connecticut) filed its triennial updated market power report with the FERC. The FERC has not yet acted on this filing. PSE&amp;G and&nbsp;ER&amp;T have received an extension from the FERC regarding the filing of their respective triennial updated market power reports, which were due to have been filed with FERC on June&nbsp;19, 2006. FERC has granted the companies an extension for filing until the later of (i)&nbsp;30 days after the close of the pending PSEG/Exelon Merger; or (ii)&nbsp;November&nbsp;30, 2006. Further, when and if the Merger is consummated, all PSEG and Exelon subsidiaries holding market based rate authority will
be required to provide appropriate updates of their market power analyses to the FERC.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G and Power</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><u><font color=#000000>PJM Schedule&nbsp;12 Filing</font></u></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>March&nbsp;31, 2006 Form&nbsp;10-Q, Page&nbsp;78. </font></b></i><font color=#000000>On January&nbsp;5, 2006, PJM for the first time proposed cost allocation recommendations for new transmission projects pursuant to Schedule&nbsp;6 of its Operating Agreement and Schedule&nbsp;12 of its Tariff. PJM identified the &ldquo;Responsible Customers&rdquo; that would be required to pay for certain transmission upgrades approved through&nbsp;PJM&#39;s Regional Transmission</font></p>
<p align=center>85</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>Expansion Planning (RTEP) process and the percentage of the project cost that would be allocated to such Responsible Customers. This was the first filing by&nbsp;PJM pursuant to these new cost allocation mechanisms and it included (i)&nbsp;large cost allocations to eastern load as a result of proposed construction in the western and southern portions of&nbsp;PJM and (ii)&nbsp;allocations to merchant transmission projects such as Neptune Regional Transmission System, LLC (Neptune) for the first time. On May&nbsp;26, 2006, the FERC issued an order that accepted and suspended&nbsp;PJM&#39;s cost allocation filing, made the filing effective subject to refund as of May&nbsp;30, 2006 and established a hearing and settlement judge procedure. The settlement proceeding is currently being conducted before a FERC Administrative Law Judge (ALJ). PSEG is actively participating
in this proceeding, as the cost allocation methodology used by&nbsp;PJM may result in a disproportionate allocation of costs to load in the eastern portion of&nbsp;PJM. PSEG, PSE&amp;G and Power are unable to predict the outcome of this proceeding at this time.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In addition, on May&nbsp;4, 2006, PJM made a second RTEP cost allocation filing at FERC under Schedules&nbsp;6 and&nbsp;12, addressing cost allocations to Responsible Customers associated with additional RTEP projects. PSEG has protested the filing, objecting to, among other things, PJM&#39;s netting of zonal impacts to allocate RTEP costs and&nbsp;PJM&#39;s failure to consider the impact of certain adjustments in determining zonal cost allocation. FERC has not yet acted on this filing. PSEG, PSE&amp;G and Power are unable to predict the outcome of this proceeding.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><u><font color=#000000>Regional through and out rates (RTOR)</font></u></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>2005 Form&nbsp;10-K, Page&nbsp;17 and March&nbsp;31, 2006 Form&nbsp;10-Q, Page&nbsp;78. </font></b></i><font color=#000000>A trial-type hearing, encompassing a review of the actual amount of lost revenues to be recovered via the Seams Elimination Charge/Cost Adjustment/Assignment (SECA) mechanism, was held in May 2006, with an initial decision expected by August&nbsp;11, 2006. In addition, in March 2006, PSE&amp;G and Power entered into a settlement with a limited group of parties in&nbsp;PJM, which settlement was certified to the FERC, under which the parties have agreed that, notwithstanding the resolution of the SECA hearing at the FERC, the parties will agree to pay and collect&nbsp;80% of SECA revenues. PSE&amp;G has deferred the collection of any SECA revenues on its books. At the present time, it is difficult
to determine whether, and to what extent, the SECA hearing will have an impact on PSEG, PSE&amp;G and Power.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><u><font color=#000000>PJM Reliability Pricing Model (RPM)</font></u></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>2005 Form&nbsp;10-K, Page&nbsp;17 and March&nbsp;31, 2006 Form&nbsp;10-Q, Page&nbsp;79. </font></b></i><font color=#000000>On August&nbsp;31, 2005, PJM filed its&nbsp;RPM with FERC. The&nbsp;RPM constitutes a locational installed capacity market design for the&nbsp;PJM region, including a forward auction for installed capacity priced according to a downward-sloping demand curve, recognition of locational value and a transitional implementation of the market design. PSEG generally supports the&nbsp;PJM approach. Following extensive comments and a technical conference, FERC issued an order on April&nbsp;20, 2006 that accepted most of the core concepts of the&nbsp;RPM filing with an implementation date of June&nbsp;1, 2007. The April&nbsp;20, 2006 order set certain details of the filing for paper hearing and technical
conference procedures including the slope of the demand curve and the mechanism for identification of the locational capacity zones. The paper hearing and technical conference procedures have now been completed. Also, commencing in June 2006, settlement discussions mediated by a FERC&nbsp;ALJ commenced at the request of certain intervenors. These discussions are currently ongoing and are being attended by representatives for&nbsp;PSE&amp;G and Power. The April&nbsp;20, 2006 order is subject to rehearing requests filed by several parties. Given the pending rehearing requests and likelihood of eventual judicial appeals, the paper hearing and technical conference procedures and the on-going settlement discussions, PSEG, PSE&amp;G and Power are unable to predict the outcome of this proceeding.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><u><font color=#000000>PJM Long-Term Transmission Rate Design</font></u></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>2005 Form&nbsp;10-K, Page&nbsp;17. </font></b></i><font color=#000000>On May&nbsp;31, 2005, FERC issued an order addressing the recovery of costs for transmission upgrades designated through&nbsp;PJM&#39;s RTEP process. Among other matters, FERC&#39;s order responded to a proposal to continue&nbsp;PJM&#39;s current zonal rate design. FERC concluded that the existing rate design may not be just and reasonable and it established a hearing to examine the justness and reasonableness of continuing&nbsp;PJM&#39;s modified zonal rate design. Several parties to the proceeding have proposed replacing zonal rate design with other rate design methodologies above certain voltage levels. A hearing in this proceeding was held in April 2006. An initial decision by the&nbsp;ALJ was issued on</font></p>
<p align=center>86</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>July&nbsp;13, 2006, in which the&nbsp;ALJ concluded that the existing&nbsp;PJM modified zonal rate design for existing facilities has been shown to be unjust and unreasonable, and should be replaced with a postage stamp rate design for such facilities to be effective April&nbsp;1, 2006. To mitigate rate impacts, the&nbsp;ALJ has determined that the rate design should be phased in, so that no customer receives greater than a&nbsp;10% annual rate increase. Should the FERC ultimately approve this postage stamp rate design on review of the&nbsp;ALJ&#39;s initial decision, or adopt one or a combination of the alternative rate designs proposed, PSEG&#39;s, PSE&amp;G&#39;s or Power&#39;s results of operations could be adversely impacted. It is not possible to predict the outcome of this proceeding at this time.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><u><font color=#000000>FERC Order&nbsp;No. 888</font></u></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>2005 Form&nbsp;10-K, Page&nbsp;18. </font></b></i><font color=#000000>On May&nbsp;18, 2006, FERC issued a Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (NOPR) seeking comments on whether reforms are needed to the protections that FERC established in its Order&nbsp;No. 888 in order to prevent undue discrimination and preference in the provision of transmission service. FERC&#39;s NOPR solicits input from the industry as to whether it should revise the pro forma Open Access Transmission Tariff. Order&nbsp;No. 888 established this tariff to govern the terms and conditions under which transmission owners must provide transmission service to all eligible customers. If FERC ultimately adopts structural remedies, such as further separating the ownership of generation and transmission, or mandates joint ownership of backbone transmission
facilities, PSEG, PSE&amp;G and Power&#39;s results of operations could be negatively affected. Comments to the NOPR are due in August 2006 and the FERC is expected to issue a Final Rule thereafter.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><u><font color=#000000>PJM Stated Rate Filing</font></u></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>2005 Form&nbsp;10-K, Page&nbsp;18 and March&nbsp;31, 2006 Form&nbsp;10-Q, Page&nbsp;79. </font></b></i><font color=#000000>On July&nbsp;1, 2005, PJM filed with FERC a proposal to change the rate design for its administrative cost recovery from a formula rate, which allocates&nbsp;PJM&#39;s administrative costs to its members on a yearly basis, to a stated rate of&nbsp;39 cents per&nbsp;MW-hour. On August&nbsp;31, 2005, FERC accepted these changes subject to the provision of further cost-of-service data by&nbsp;PJM within&nbsp;60 days to demonstrate that its stated rate is a just and reasonable prediction of its costs for future years. PJM provided this cost-of-service data on November&nbsp;30, 2005. Several parties, including&nbsp;PSE&amp;G, Power, the&nbsp;BPU and the New Jersey Ratepayer Advocate (RPA), submitted
comments and protests regarding&nbsp;PJM&#39;s filing, which protested the filing and requested that FERC order an evidentiary hearing regarding the filing. Settlement discussions were conducted over the course of several months, and a settlement was reached establishing a base stated rate that is significantly lower than&nbsp;PJM&#39;s filed rate, establishing a rate for&nbsp;PJM&#39;s proposed second control center and establishing a revised protocol to govern future interaction among the&nbsp;PJM Finance Committee, PJM management, PJM&#39;s Board of Managers and the&nbsp;PJM membership, revisions which will result in the Finance Committee having greater access to&nbsp;PJM financial information and greater input into&nbsp;PJM&#39;s financial decision making processes. The uncontested settlement was filed with the FERC on April&nbsp;18, 2006 and was approved by the FERC on May&nbsp;26, 2006.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><u><font color=#000000>Locational Installed Capacity (LICAP) Market Settlement in New England</font></u></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>2005 Form&nbsp;10-K, Page&nbsp;18. </font></b></i><font color=#000000>On January&nbsp;31, 2006, certain interested market participants in New England agreed to a settlement in principle of litigation regarding the design of the region&#39;s market for installed capacity, which would institute a transition period leading to the implementation of a new market design for capacity as early as 2010. Commencing in December 2006, all generators in New England would begin to receive fixed capacity payments that escalate gradually over the transition period. RMR contracts, such as Power&#39;s, would continue to be effective until the implementation of the new market design. The new market design would consist of a forward auction for installed capacity that is intended to recognize the locational value of generators on the
system, and contains incentive mechanisms to encourage generator availability during generation shortages. The final version of the settlement was filed with the FERC on March&nbsp;6, 2006 and was approved by order dated June&nbsp;16, 2006 finding that, as a package, the settlement represents a just and reasonable outcome. The settlement was contested by certain parties and it is anticipated that rehearing of the June&nbsp;16, 2006 order will be sought. PSEG and Power are unable to predict the outcome of this proceeding.</font></p>
<p align=center>87</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><u><font color=#000000>RMR Status</font></u></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>PJM</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>2005 Form&nbsp;10-K, Page&nbsp;18. </font></b></i><font color=#000000>Effective February&nbsp;24, 2005, subject to refund and hearing, Power began to collect a monthly fixed payment of $3.3 million, net of operating margins for the Sewaren&nbsp;1, 2, 3 and&nbsp;4 and Hudson&nbsp;1 units. A detailed settlement was filed with FERC on September&nbsp;23, 2005 that permits Power to recover annual fixed costs of approximately $19 million and $14.5 million for the Sewaren and Hudson units, respectively, plus reimbursements of Power&#39;s expenditures in connection with certain construction at the units that are necessary to maintain reliability, offset by certain revenues earned in&nbsp;PJM&#39;s energy market. FERC accepted this settlement retroactive to February&nbsp;24, 2005. On March&nbsp;28, 2006, Power filed a refund
report with FERC seeking to recover $11 million paid to&nbsp;PJM. FERC did not issue a public notice requesting comments on the report and no party has made any objections or other comments with respect to the report.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>New England</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>2005 Form&nbsp;10-K, Page&nbsp;19 and March&nbsp;31, 2006 Form&nbsp;10-Q, Page&nbsp;79. </font></b></i><font color=#000000>On November&nbsp;17, 2004, Power Connecticut, a wholly owned indirect subsidiary of Power, filed a request for&nbsp;RMR treatment for the Unit&nbsp;2 at the Bridgeport Harbor generation station and New Haven Harbor generation station. Beginning on January&nbsp;14, 2005, when FERC issued an order accepting this filing, subject to refund and hearing, Power Connecticut began collecting monthly fixed payments of approximately $1.6 million and $3.9 million for reliability services provided by the Bridgeport Harbor Station, Unit&nbsp;2 and the New Haven Harbor Station, respectively, net of operating margins at the units. On June&nbsp;17, 2005, Power Connecticut filed revised studies supporting monthly
recovery of $1.3 million and $3.3 million for the Bridgeport Harbor&nbsp;2 and New Haven Harbor units, respectively.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On June&nbsp;20, 2005, FERC issued an order on rehearing of its January&nbsp;14, 2005 order and reversed its prior conclusion that Power Connecticut&#39;s November&nbsp;17, 2004 filing would become effective only after a&nbsp;60-day notice period. Instead, the rehearing order allowed the filing to become effective as of November&nbsp;18, 2004, which permits Power Connecticut two additional months of&nbsp;RMR compensation. On November&nbsp;28, 2005, FERC denied rehearing of its June&nbsp;20, 2005 order. Certain parties opposing the&nbsp;RMR filing, on January&nbsp;27, 2006, sought judicial review of the FERC&#39;s orders in this proceeding.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>FERC assigned this matter to an&nbsp;ALJ for hearings that were scheduled to commence on April&nbsp;19, 2006. Power Connecticut and the affected intervenors have, nonetheless, continued to engage in settlement discussions, and on April&nbsp;21, 2006, Power Connecticut, the Connecticut Department of Public Utility Control, the Connecticut Office of Consumer Counsel and&nbsp;ISO New England Inc. filed with the FERC a Joint Stipulation and Settlement Agreement and Motion for Expedited Consideration. The Joint Stipulation and Settlement settled all matters associated with the&nbsp;RMR agreements filed by Power Connecticut for its Bridgeport Harbor&nbsp;2 and New Haven Harbor stations. Among other things, the settlement provides for monthly fixed payments of approximately $1 million for Bridgeport Harbor and $3 million for New
Haven Harbor. Trial Staff for the FERC also supports the settlement. The only disputed issues concern the standard of review applicable to certain types of potential tariff changes that could be filed in the future. No party challenges the settlement rates proposed to become effective at this time. The&nbsp;ALJ certified the settlement to FERC on June&nbsp;21, 2006 as a contested offer of settlement. It is anticipated that the settlement, which resolves all issues set for hearing by FERC as well as issues raised in the appellate courts, will be approved as certified or, if modified, will not be modified in a manner that adversely affects the settlement rates. However, Power Connecticut cannot predict a final outcome at this time.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><u><font color=#000000>Neptune Complaint Proceeding</font></u></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>2005 Form&nbsp;10-K, Page&nbsp;19. </font></b></i><font color=#000000>On December&nbsp;21, 2004, Neptune filed a complaint with FERC against&nbsp;PJM. Neptune is directly interconnected to the transmission system of FirstEnergy Corporation (FirstEnergy), but upgrades to the&nbsp;PSE&amp;G transmission system will also be required to move power across the grid. In its complaint, Neptune alleges that&nbsp;PJM impermissibly conducted an interconnection re-study triggered by generator retirements in&nbsp;PJM, which had the effect of increasing Neptune&#39;s cost</font></p>
<p align=center>88</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>exposure for network upgrades. On February&nbsp;10, 2005, FERC granted Neptune&#39;s complaint against&nbsp;PJM and then denied rehearing on June&nbsp;24, 2005. As a result of these orders, Neptune&#39;s interconnection cost responsibility was capped at a level of approximately $6 million, and the remaining $20 million in interconnection costs may ultimately be allocated to the customers of&nbsp;PSE&amp;G and FirstEnergy and flowed through to retail ratepayers should pass-through of these costs be permitted.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On August&nbsp;15, 2005, PSE&amp;G sought judicial review of FERC&#39;s orders in the&nbsp;U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. Two additional petitioners also sought judicial review of these orders, and the&nbsp;BPU and&nbsp;RPA have intervened in the case. Initial briefs in the case have been filed and reply briefs are due in August 2006. PSE&amp;G cannot at this time predict the outcome of this appeal.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><u><font color=#000000>LDV Complaint Proceeding</font></u></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On December&nbsp;30, 2004, Jersey Central Power &amp; Light Company (JCP&amp;L) filed a complaint at the FERC against the other four signatories to the Lower Delaware Valley (LDV) Transmission System Agreement, including&nbsp;PSE&amp;G. The&nbsp;LDV Agreement, governing the construction of, and investment in, certain&nbsp;500 kV transmission facilities in New Jersey, was entered into by the parties in 1977 and remains in effect until 2027. In the FERC complaint proceeding, JCP&amp;L seeks to terminate its payment obligations to the other contract signatories. PSE&amp;G receives from&nbsp;JCP&amp;L approximately $2.7 million annually under the&nbsp;LDV Agreement and its related agreements. On May&nbsp;6, 2005, the FERC issued an order dismissing&nbsp;JCP&amp;L&#39;s complaint. Subsequently, in a rehearing order issued December&nbsp;2,
2005, the FERC set certain issues raised by&nbsp;JCP&amp;L for hearing. The parties engaged in settlement discussions from January 2006 through May 2006, and these efforts proved unsuccessful. The matter is now in litigation, with a hearing scheduled to take place in November 2006 and an initial decision to be rendered by the&nbsp;ALJ in March 2007. It is anticipated that&nbsp;JCP&amp;L will seek not only to terminate its payment obligations but also to seek approximately $40 million in credits from&nbsp;PSE&amp;G and the other&nbsp;LDV parties for transmission facilities previously constructed by&nbsp;JCP&amp;L in New Jersey. PSE&amp;G cannot predict the outcome of this proceeding.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>NRC</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><u><font color=#000000>Nuclear Safety Issues</font></u></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>2005 Form&nbsp;10-K, Page&nbsp;20. </font></b></i><font color=#000000>In January 2004, the&nbsp;NRC issued a letter requesting Power to conduct a review of its Salem and Hope Creek nuclear generation facilities to assess the workplace environment for raising and addressing safety issues. Power responded to the letter in February 2004 and had independent assessments of the work environment at both facilities performed. The results of these assessments were provided to the&nbsp;NRC in May 2004. The assessments concluded that Salem and Hope Creek were safe for continued operations, but also identified issues that needed to be addressed.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>At an&nbsp;NRC public meeting on June&nbsp;16, 2004, Power outlined its action plan to address these issues, which focused on a safety-conscious work environment, the corrective action program and work management. A letter documenting these plans and commitments was sent to the&nbsp;NRC on June&nbsp;25, 2004. On July&nbsp;30, 2004, the&nbsp;NRC provided a letter to Power indicating that it had completed its review. The letter indicated that the&nbsp;NRC had not identified any safety violations and that it appeared that the PSEG action plan would address the key findings of both the&nbsp;NRC and Power assessments. On March&nbsp;2, 2006, the&nbsp;NRC provided Power with its annual performance reviews of Salem and Hope Creek, which detailed the&nbsp;NRC&#39;s plan for enhanced oversight related to the work environment. The
letter indicated the&nbsp;NRC plans to continue with this heightened oversight until Power has concluded that substantial, sustainable progress has been made, and the&nbsp;NRC has completed a review that confirms Power&#39;s conclusions. Under the&nbsp;NRC oversight program, Power provided the&nbsp;NRC with a report of its progress at a public meeting in May 2006.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><u><font color=#000000>Recirculation Pump</font></u></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>2005 Form&nbsp;10-K, Page&nbsp;21. </font></b></i><font color=#000000>In a letter to the&nbsp;NRC dated January&nbsp;9, 2005, Power committed to install vibration-monitoring equipment on Hope Creek&#39;s &ldquo;B&rdquo; Reactor Recirculation Pump prior to the</font></p>
<p align=center>89</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>unit&#39;s return to service to address pump vibration concerns and replace the pump&#39;s shaft during the next refueling outage or any sooner outage of sufficient duration. This commitment was the subject of a January&nbsp;11, 2005 Confirmatory Action Letter from the&nbsp;NRC. The shaft was replaced during the Hope Creek outage in April 2006. On April&nbsp;20, 2006, the&nbsp;NRC issued a Closure of Confirmatory Action Letter indicating that all of the commitments were completed.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>State Regulation</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>PUHCA Repeal</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>2005 Form&nbsp;10-K, Page&nbsp;21 and March&nbsp;31, 2006 Form&nbsp;10-Q, Page&nbsp;80. </font></b></i><font color=#000000>On March&nbsp;31, 2006, the&nbsp;BPU issued draft proposed rules in this proceeding. Specifically, these proposed rules would preserve and further codify the&nbsp;BPU&#39;s access to both utility and utility holding company system books and records, establish ring-fencing measures around the utility, seek to separate the corporate boards of directors between the utility and its holding company system, and address issues regarding the extent of the&nbsp;BPU&#39;s oversight of service agreements between a utility and its holding company system. All of the New Jersey electric and gas utilities, including&nbsp;PSE&amp;G, submitted a revised rulemaking proposal to the&nbsp;BPU on these issues, as well
as on transitional and grandfathering issues that would allow the utilities sufficient time to comply with new rules and that would provide for the continuing validity of previously-issued BPU orders. Comments were filed by all parties to this proceeding on June&nbsp;15, 2006. The&nbsp;BPU has not yet issued final rules in this proceeding. PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings are not able to predict the outcome of these proceedings at this time.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>BGS Auction Review</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In 2006, the&nbsp;BPU initiated a proceeding to review the annual&nbsp;BGS procurement process as well as the policy issues thereto for all of the New Jersey EDCs. In June 2006, the&nbsp;BPU ruled on certain issues regarding the acquisition of&nbsp;BGS for the period beginning in June 2007. The&nbsp;BPU agreed that a descending clock auction format should be used for the procurement of&nbsp;BGS-FP supply for 2007. The&nbsp;BPU also agreed that&nbsp;BGS suppliers should not be required to disclose the sources of supply behind the&nbsp;BGS contracts.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On July&nbsp;10, 2006, PSE&amp;G filed the Joint&nbsp;EDC proposal for the procurement of&nbsp;BGS for the period beginning June&nbsp;1, 2007. This proposal includes a descending clock auction format to be held in February 2007 for the procurement of all&nbsp;BGS supply. A decision by the&nbsp;BPU on this proposal is expected in the third quarter of 2006. PSE&amp;G cannot predict the outcome of this proceeding.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Electric Distribution Financial Review</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>2005 Form&nbsp;10-K, Page&nbsp;22 and March&nbsp;31, 2006 Form&nbsp;10-Q, Page&nbsp;81. </font></b></i><font color=#000000>Based on the Electric Base Rate Case approved in July 2003, PSE&amp;G recorded a regulatory liability in the second quarter of 2003 by reducing its depreciation reserve for its electric distribution assets by $155 million and amortized this liability from August&nbsp;1, 2003 through December&nbsp;31, 2005. The $64 million annual amortization of this liability resulted in a reduction of Depreciation and Amortization expense. PSE&amp;G filed for the elimination of the $64 million (based on 2003 test year sales volumes) electric distribution rate credit effective January&nbsp;1, 2006, subject to&nbsp;BPU approval, including a review of&nbsp;PSE&amp;G&#39;s earnings and other relevant financial information.
Based on current sales volumes, the amount approximates $68 million.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The&nbsp;BPU issued an order on February&nbsp;7, 2006 that found that insufficient information had been provided to support the elimination of the rate credit. The order permitted&nbsp;PSE&amp;G to file actual data through March&nbsp;31, 2006. The&nbsp;BPU will determine, based on the additional information, if the elimination of the rate credit is warranted. The impact of not eliminating the depreciation rate credit reduces&nbsp;PSE&amp;G&#39;s earnings and cash flows by more than $5 million (pre-tax) per month. PSE&amp;G filed an update of the original data containing first quarter 2006 actual financial information on June&nbsp;14, 2006. Action on&nbsp;PSE&amp;G&#39;s recent filings, including the excess depreciation rate credit, has been subject to</font></p>
<p align=center>90</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>ongoing delays. It appears that until the Merger is resolved with the&nbsp;BPU, decisions on&nbsp;PSE&amp;G&#39;s revenue requests may be difficult to achieve.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>BGSS Filings</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>2005 Form&nbsp;10-K, Page&nbsp;22 and March&nbsp;31, 2006 Form&nbsp;10-Q, Page&nbsp;81. </font></b></i><font color=#000000>On March&nbsp;8, 2006 a meeting of&nbsp;PSE&amp;G, the&nbsp;BPU and the&nbsp;RPA was held regarding the BGSS rates for the 2005/2006 period. PSE&amp;G addressed the&nbsp;RPA&#39;s discovery concerns, however the&nbsp;RPA requested that the BGSS not be finalized until the Merger case is resolved.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The schedule at the Office of Administrative Law (OAL) called for the&nbsp;RPA&#39;s testimony to be filed on March&nbsp;15, 2006. The&nbsp;RPA failed to file and subsequently argued that the 2005/2006 BGSS proceeding be held in abeyance until the Merger case is resolved. The&nbsp;ALJ directed the&nbsp;RPA to file a motion, which was subsequently filed. The motion requested that the BGSS proceeding be stayed, or that it be consolidated with the Gas Base Rate Case. PSE&amp;G filed its reply on April&nbsp;5, 2006 arguing that the issues of the two proceedings are unrelated and that the&nbsp;RPA&#39;s motion had no merit. The&nbsp;ALJ denied the&nbsp;RPA&#39;s motion to combine the BGSS proceeding with the Gas Base Rate Case. The&nbsp;RPA filed its testimony on May&nbsp;26, 2006 on several gas contract related issues. PSE&amp;G
filed rebuttal testimony on June&nbsp;22, 2006 on the gas contract issues. A hearing was held on June&nbsp;29, 2006 after a settlement could not be reached. The parties agreed that the BGSS Commodity Charge increases of September&nbsp;1, 2005 and December&nbsp;15, 2005 that were previously approved by the&nbsp;BPU on a provisional basis should become final. The remaining gas contract issues are pending.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G made its 2006/2007 BGSS filing on May&nbsp;26, 2006. In this filing, PSE&amp;G requested a reduction in annual BGSS gas revenues of approximately $19.7 million (excluding losses and New Jersey Sales and Use Tax) or approximately a&nbsp;1.0% decrease to be implemented for service rendered on and after October&nbsp;1, 2006 or earlier. Additionally, PSE&amp;G requested an increase in its Balancing Charge. The combined impact of both changes for the class average residential heating customer is an increase in the winter monthly bills of approximately&nbsp;0.1%; however, on an annual basis the impact is a decrease of approximately&nbsp;0.2%.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Gas Base Rate Case</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>2005 Form&nbsp;10-K, Page&nbsp;23 and March&nbsp;31, 2006 Form&nbsp;10-Q, Page&nbsp;81. </font></b></i><font color=#000000>On September&nbsp;30, 2005, PSE&amp;G filed a petition with the&nbsp;BPU seeking an overall&nbsp;3.78% increase in its gas base rates to cover the cost of gas delivery to be effective June&nbsp;30, 2006. Approximately $55 million of the $133 million request is for an increase in book depreciation rates. The balance of the request will cover the return on increased plant investment, higher operating expenses and provide an&nbsp;11% return on equity. PSE&amp;G&#39;s current gas base rates have been in effect since January 2002.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G presented a detailed overview of the filing to the&nbsp;BPU and the&nbsp;RPA in October 2005 and subsequent to the presentation signed an agreement with the&nbsp;BPU Staff providing for transfer of the matter to the&nbsp;OAL and agreeing to have the matter settled or ready for a&nbsp;BPU decision before September&nbsp;28, 2006.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On March&nbsp;15, 2006, a pre-hearing conference was held for the parties and a schedule set for public hearings, direct and rebuttal testimony, evidentiary hearings and briefs, with an&nbsp;ALJ decision by late October and a&nbsp;BPU decision by early December 2006. Discovery commenced and will be conducted on a rolling basis.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On June&nbsp;15, 2006 and June&nbsp;21, 2006, the&nbsp;RPA and Intervenors filed direct testimony and&nbsp;PSE&amp;G filed rebuttal testimony on June&nbsp;30, 2006 and July&nbsp;14, 2006. The&nbsp;RPA recommended a $70 million rate decrease. Evidentiary hearings commenced on July&nbsp;21, 2006 and will continue into mid August 2006.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Action on&nbsp;PSE&amp;G&#39;s recent filings, including the Gas Base Rate Case, has been subject to ongoing delays. It appears that until the Merger is resolved with the&nbsp;BPU, decisions on&nbsp;PSE&amp;G&#39;s revenue requests may be difficult to achieve.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>CAS Cost Recovery Mechanism</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>2005 Form&nbsp;10-K, Page&nbsp;23 and March&nbsp;31, 2006 Form&nbsp;10-Q, Page&nbsp;82. </font></b></i><font color=#000000>The New Jersey Electric Discount and Energy Competition Act (EDECA) required that the&nbsp;BPU provide electric and natural</font></p>
<p align=center>91</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>gas customers with the opportunity to choose a supplier for some or all electric or natural gas customer account services (CAS). In July 2004, PSE&amp;G filed a petition with the&nbsp;BPU to implement the&nbsp;CAS Cost Recovery Mechanism for both its electric and gas operations to recover $4 million of&nbsp;CAS costs and accumulated interest resulting from implementing&nbsp;PSE&amp;G&#39;s dual billing for its delivery costs and for the third-party suppliers&#39; commodity charges as a result of customer migration from&nbsp;PSE&amp;G. In September 2004, the case was transferred to the&nbsp;OAL as a contested case. A pre-hearing conference was held on December&nbsp;20, 2005 at which time a schedule was established. On April&nbsp;7, 2006, a settlement agreement was reached and filed with the&nbsp;ALJ.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On May&nbsp;17, 2006, the&nbsp;BPU issued its Order approving the Initial Decision&ndash;Settlement that fully resolved this matter. The Settlement will allow&nbsp;PSE&amp;G to recover a total of $3.3 million of costs over a one-year period. Recovery will begin as of the date of the next base rate change or January&nbsp;1, 2007, whichever is earlier.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>ENVIRONMENTAL MATTERS</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Carbon Dioxide (CO</font></b><b><font color=#000000><small><sub>2</sub></small></font></b><b><font color=#000000>) Emissions</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>2005 Form&nbsp;10-K, Page&nbsp;27 and March&nbsp;31, 2006 Form&nbsp;10-Q, Page&nbsp;82. </font></b></i><font color=#000000>Several states, primarily in the Northeastern&nbsp;U.S., are developing state-specific or regional legislative initiatives to stimulate CO</font><font color=#000000><small><sub>2</sub></small></font><font color=#000000> emission reductions in the electric power industry. New York initiated the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative (RGGI) in April 2003. Currently, in the RGGI, seven Northeastern states have signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) intended to cap and reduce CO</font><font color=#000000><small><sub>2</sub></small></font><font color=#000000> emissions from the electric power sector in the RGGI region. A draft model rule was issued on March&nbsp;23, 2006 but stakeholder comments are
being received and the model rule has not been finalized. States are expected to enact legislation and/or regulation representing, at least, the minimum requirements stipulated in the&nbsp;MOU. The NJDEP in 2005 finalized amendments to its regulations governing air pollution control that would designate CO</font><font color=#000000><small><sub>2</sub></small></font><font color=#000000> as an air contaminant subject to regulation. The RGGI program is scheduled to start in 2009. The outcome of this initiative cannot be determined at this time; however, adoption of stringent CO</font><font color=#000000><small><sub>2</sub></small></font><font color=#000000> emission reduction requirements in the Northeast could materially impact Power&#39;s operation of its fossil fuel-fired electric generating units.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G and Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Remedial Investigation/Feasibility Study</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Form&nbsp;10-Q, page&nbsp;82. </font></b></i><font color=#000000>On March&nbsp;9, 2006, the&nbsp;EPA sent&nbsp;PSE&amp;G, Power and approximately&nbsp;157 other entities a notice that the&nbsp;EPA considered each of the entities to be a potentially responsible party (PRP) with respect to contamination in Berry&#39;s Creek in Bergen County, New Jersey and requesting that the PRPs perform a Remedial Investigation/Feasibility Study (RI/FS) on Berry&#39;s Creek and the connected tributaries and wetlands. Berry&#39;s Creek flows through approximately&nbsp;6.5 miles of areas that have been used for a variety of industrial purposes and landfills. The&nbsp;EPA estimates that the study could be completed in approximately five years at a total cost of approximately $18 million. PSE&amp;G and Power are unable to predict the
outcome of this matter; however, the related costs are not expected to be material.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>GWF</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In April 2006, GWF Power Systems, L.P. and Hanford&nbsp;L.P., each a partnership&nbsp;50% owned by Global, executed amendments to their respective power purchase agreements to establish fixed price energy sales terms for a five-year period. The California Public Utilities Commission approved the amendments on July&nbsp;20, 2006, which started a&nbsp;30-day period for parties in the proceeding to appeal or request rehearing. The amendments will be effective, and the five-year term will commence, at the end of the&nbsp;30-day period if rehearing is not required.</font></p>
<p align=center>92</p>

<p align=center><b><font color=#000000><a name='signatures'>SIGNATURE</a></font></b></p>
